{{Infobox company | name = Cogeco Peer 1 | logo = Cogeco Peer 1 logo.svg | type = [[Subsidiary]] | key_people = Philippe Jetté, President
Jaime Leverton, Vice President and General Manager, Canada and APAC
Susan Bowen, Vice President and General Manager, [[Europe, the Middle East and Africa|EMEA]]
Cynthia Jordan-Ford, Vice President and General Manager, [[Latin America|LATAM]] & US | industry = [[Cloud Computing]], [[Internet hosting service|Hosting]] | parent = [[Cogeco Communications Inc.]]
[[Cogeco Inc.]] | homepage = https://www.cogecopeer1.com | location = 413 Horner Avenue
Etobicoke, ON, Canada   M8W 4W3 | foundation = 2015 }} '''Cogeco Peer 1''' is a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Cogeco Communications Inc.]] which provides business-to-business products and services, such as [[colocation centre|colocation]], [[Internet access|network connectivity]], [[managed hosting]], [[cloud services]] and [[Managed services|IT managed services]].2016 Annual Report "[http://corpo.cogeco.com/cca/files/8414/7853/4141/CCA.Q4.2016_-_Annual_Report_website_only.pdf]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. Cogeco Peer 1 is headquartered in [[Toronto]], ON, [[Canada]]. ==History== On October 19, 2015, Cogeco Cable Inc. announced the unification of two of their subsidiaries, Cogeco Data Services and Peer 1 Hosting.Presenting Cogeco Peer 1 "[http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/presenting-cogeco-peer-1-tsx-cca-2064985.htm]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. '''Cogeco Data Services''' * On April 1, 2008, Cogeco acquired '''MaXess Networx''', a division of EnWin Utilities.Cogeco Cable completes the acquisition of MaXess Networx® "[http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/cogeco-cable-completes-the-acquisition-of-maxess-networx-839070.htm]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. * On June 13, 2008, Cogeco acquired the Telecommunications division of [[Toronto Hydro]], Toronto's municipal electric utility.Cogeco Cable acquires Toronto Hydro Telecom Inc. "[http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/cogeco-cable-acquires-toronto-hydro-telecom-inc-tsx-cca-868567.htm]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. On July 31, 2008, '''Toronto Hydro Telecom''' sold all the shares to Cogeco Cable Canada Inc. and became Cogeco Data Services.Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations for the Year Ended "[https://www.torontohydro.com/sites/corporate/InvestorRelations/FinancialReports/Financial%20Report/MDA%20Dec08%20OSC%20FINAL.pdf]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. * On August 2, 2011, Cogeco Cable acquired '''Quiettouch Inc.''' and was integrated under Cogeco Data Services to complement their array of services.Cogeco Cable Completes the Acquisition of Quiettouch Inc. "[https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/Cogeco-Cable-Completes-marketwire-842561185.html]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. * On August 31, 2011, Cogeco Cable acquired '''MTO Telecom Inc.''' (the largest private telecom provider and [[Fiber-optic communication|fibre network]] operator in the [[Montreal]] greater area) and was integrated under Cogeco Data Services to expand CDS' presence in the Province of [[Quebec]].Cogeco Cable Acquires Montreal's MTO Telecom "[https://www.yahoo.com/news/Cogeco-Cable-Acquires-ccn-3993929601.html]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. '''Peer 1 Hosting''' The company was founded in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada in 1999 by Lance Tracey and Mark Teolis.Fabio Banducci, President and CEO, Peer 1 Hosting shares his deep expertise "[https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/cdnitmanagers/2010/12/22/fabio-banducci-president-and-ceo-peer-1-hosting-shares-his-deep-expertise/]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. From the beginning, the co-founders targeted small- and medium-sized business customers. Peer 1 Hosting offered colocation, dedicated servers, managed hosting, private cloud services, cloud storage, hosted email, and cloud-based graphics processing.Peer 1 Dedicated Hosting Review "[http://www.webhostingjungle.com/peer1/review.shtml]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. * In 2004, the company acquired '''ServerBeach''', a dedicated hosting provider located in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], for $US7.5 million.Peer 1 Acquires ServerBeach "[http://www.thewhir.com/web-hosting-news/peer-1-acquires-serverbeach]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. * In 2007, the company introduced an incubation program that combined discounted hosting services with consulting assistants.Peer 1 promises cheaper, easier SaaS for ISVs "[http://www.itworldcanada.com/article/peer-1-promises-cheaper-easier-saas-for-isvs/10040]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. In 2010, the company built a new energy-efficient and green data center located just outside Toronto.Peer 1 unveils flagship data centre in Toronto "[http://www.networkworld.com/article/2245405/data-center/peer-1-unveils-flagship-data-centre-in-toronto.html]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. * To provide [[Internet]] users with a visual perspective into online traffic flows, the company developed a graphical "Map of the Internet" that depicts the layout of all the networks that connect to form the Internet.Ever wonder what the Internet looks like? "[http://business.financialpost.com/fp-tech-desk/ever-wonder-what-the-internet-looks-like?__lsa=deca-462f]." Retrieved November 7, 2016.Check out This Beautiful Map of the Internet "[https://gigaom.com/2011/03/01/check-out-this-beautiful-map-of-the-internet/]." Retrieved November 7, 2016.The Internet looks like a golden flower... "[http://www.zdnet.com/article/the-internet-looks-like-a-golden-flower/?tag=mantle_skin;content]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. Much of the data was collected from the '''Cooperative Association for Internet Data Analysis''' (CAIDA). In 2013, the company launched an interactive [[mobile app]] version.Map of the Internet: This mobile app visualizes the Internet in 3D "[https://thenextweb.com/apps/2013/03/08/map-of-the-internet-this-mobile-app-visualizes-the-internet-in-3d/]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. * On November 7, 2011, Peer 1 announced launching its new cloud division Zunicore.Web Host PEER 1 Creates New Division to Launch Public Cloud "[http://www.thewhir.com/web-hosting-news/web-host-peer-1-creates-new-division-to-launch-public-cloud]." Retrieved November 7, 2016.Inside PEER 1's New Public Cloud Division Zunicore "[http://www.thewhir.com/web-hosting-news/inside-peer-1s-new-public-cloud-division-zunicore]." Retrieved November 7, 2016. ==Services offered== * Cloud * Hosting * Managed IT Services * Network Connectivity * Colocation Cogeco Peer 1 provides these services in the following vertical markets: online retail, financial services, technology, public sector, education, health care, business services, manufacturing, media and online gaming. ==Locations== * United States: Atlanta, Miami, San Antonio, Herndon, Los AngelesCogeco Peer 1 Website "[https://www.cogecopeer1.com/en/contact-us/]." Retrieved November 9, 2016. * United Kingdom: London, Southampton, Portsmouth * France: Nice, Paris * Canada: Toronto, Vancouver, Montreal More than 50 points of presence, including in Germany, the Netherlands and Mexico. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://www.cogecopeer1.com/en/ Company website, English] * [https://www.cogecopeer1.com/fr/ Company website, French] [[Category:Cogeco]] [[Category:Companies formerly listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Internet hosting]] [[Category:Cloud computing providers]] [[Category:Cloud platforms]] [[Category:Cloud infrastructure]] [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Information technology companies of Canada]] [[Category:Information systems]]

[[Image:Colorado for Family Values Logo.gif|thumb|right|200px|Logo of Colorado for Family Values.]] '''Colorado for Family Values''' is a [[Social conservatism in the United States|socially conservative]] [[advocacy group]] in [[Colorado]], United States.<ref name="gluckman">Amy Gluckman, Betsy Reed, ''Homo economics: capitalism, community, and lesbian and gay life'', Routledge, 1997 [https://books.google.com/books?id=6cfGMIaAm-QC&pg=PA213&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=28OsTtqwK4_ItAbU89QD&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref>
==Overview== It was co-founded by Tony Marco, Kevin Tebedo and David Noebel in the early 1990s.<ref name="gluckman"/><ref name="herma">Didi Herma, ''The Antigay Agenda: Orthodox Vision and the Christian Right'', University of Chicago Press, 1998, p. 222 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xw7332sc5zoC&pg=PA222&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=28OsTtqwK4_ItAbU89QD&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref> Will Perkins, a former car dealer from [[Colorado Springs]], is the Chairman of the Board.<ref name="herma"/><ref>Craig A. Rimmerman, ''From identity to politics: the lesbian and gay movements in the United States'', Temple University Press, 2002, p. 143 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0BexugIsxsC&pg=PA143&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=kcysTunVCNGRswbB8_iwCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref> Originally, it was called the Colorado Coalition for Family Values, but they dropped the word 'coalition' after a [[radio]] presenter said it sounded [[Marxist]].<ref name="balmer">Randall Balmer, Lauren F. Winner, ''Protestantism in America'', Columbia University Press, 2005, p. 160 [https://books.google.com/books?id=hMVH6upbI9QC&pg=PA160&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=28OsTtqwK4_ItAbU89QD&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref> Some have argued, because of the proximity of timing for the moving of Focus on the Family to Colorado Springs, that [[James Dobson]]'s move to [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]] in 1991 led to its establishment. However, it was truly coincidental timing as Focus on the Family had nothing to do with the founding of Colorado for Family Values. Dobson's [[Focus on the Family]] is independent from CFV.<ref>Chip Berlet (ed.), ''Eyes right!: challenging the right wing backlash'', South End Press, 1995, p. 93 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Fl6Ix9HFKQEC&pg=PA93&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=28OsTtqwK4_ItAbU89QD&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref><ref>Martha Craven Nussbaum, ''From disgust to humanity: sexual orientation and constitutional law'', Oxford University Press, 2010 [https://books.google.com/books?id=-Oq3katPB40C&pg=PT124&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=28OsTtqwK4_ItAbU89QD&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref> It has also been linked to [[Traditional Values]], [[Summit Ministries]], [[Concerned Women for America]], and the [[Eagle Forum]].<ref name="gluckman"/> [[Bill McCartney]], the founder of [[Promise Keepers]], is a supporter.<ref name="balmer"/><ref>Christopher J. Eberle, ''Religious conviction in liberal politics'', Cambridge University Press, 2002, p. 4 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Xib1Bxjz-9EC&pg=PA4&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=kcysTunVCNGRswbB8_iwCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref>
Colorado for Family Values (CFV) was created specifically for the purpose of countering an objective of the Colorado Human Relations Commission, to introduce legislation that would effectively add the behavior of homosexuality to the list of protected class status, thus creating the legal process of strict scruntiny for claims of discrimination made by homosexual individuals. It drafted and promoted Amendment 2 in 1992, which led to the United States Supreme Court case ''[[Romer v. Evans]]''.<ref>Daniel A. Smith, ''Tax crusaders and the politics of direct democracy'', Routledge, 1998, p. 129 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Dv1eeixQ99UC&pg=PA129&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=28OsTtqwK4_ItAbU89QD&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref><ref>Glenda Marie Russell, ''Voted out: the psychological consequences of anti-gay politics'', NYU Press, 2000, p. 2 [https://books.google.com/books?id=TVTJfqDKZkYC&pg=PA2&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=kcysTunVCNGRswbB8_iwCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref><ref>Paul Ryan Brewer, ''Value war: public opinion and the politics of gay rights'', Rowman & Littlefield, 2008, p. 2 [https://books.google.com/books?id=U34pJTdF-VcC&pg=PA2&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=kcysTunVCNGRswbB8_iwCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref><ref>Steven G. Brint, Jean Reith Schroedel, ''Evangelicals and Democracy in America: Religion and politics'', Russell Sage Foundation, 2009, p. 227 [https://books.google.com/books?id=O-QRWP4FlVEC&pg=PA227&dq=%22Colorado+for+Family+Values%22&hl=en&ei=kcysTunVCNGRswbB8_iwCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Colorado%20for%20Family%20Values%22&f=false]</ref>

'''Consideration and Initiating Structure''' are two dimensions of [[leader]] behavior identified in 1945 as a result of the Ohio State Leadership Studies. Reviews of research on these dimensions are in Ralph M. Stogdill (1974): ''Handbook of leadership: A survey of theory and research''. [[New York City|New York]], NY, US: Free Press; and Littrell, R.F. (2013).
According to the findings of these studies, leaders exhibit two types of [[behaviors]] to facilitate [[goal]] accomplishment: * People-oriented (consideration) * [[Task (project management)|Task]] oriented (initiating structure)
The model is similar to the [[Michigan Studies of Leadership]].
In his Handbook, Stogdill expanded the model to twelve [[dimensions]].
== Ohio State Leadership Studies == Prior to 1945 most studies of [[leadership]] sought to identify the individual [[trait theory|traits]] of effective leaders.
[[Trait theory|Trait theories]] of leadership were the first to attempt a systematic approach of studying [[leadership]]. However, these studies yielded disappointing results when no set of traits were found that explained effective leadership.
In 1945, a group of researchers at the [[Ohio State University]] sought to identify the observable [[behaviors]] of leaders instead of identifying [[personality traits]]. === Leaders Behavior Description Questionnaire (LBDQ) === To accomplish this they generated a list of 1790 statements. This was narrowed down to 150 statements designed to measure nine different dimensions of leader behavior. These statements were used to develop the Leaders Behavior Description Questionnaire (LBDQ).<ref name="cyfar.org">{{cite web|last1=Originated by staff members of The Ohio State Leadership Studies And revised by Bureau of Business Research|title=LEADER BEHAVIOR DESCRIPTION QUESTIONNAIRE – Form XII Self|url=https://cyfar.org/sites/default/files/LBDQ_1962_Self_Assessment.pdf|website=cyfar.org|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
After further research, the LBDQ-XII, was developed, assessing 12 factors/dimensions of leader behavior. See Stogdill (1963).<ref name="Ralph M. Stogdill">{{cite book|last1=Ralph M. Stogdill|title=LEADER BEHAVIOR DESCRIPTION QUESTIONNAIRE|date=1963|publisher=Fisher College of Business, The Ohio State University|url=https://fisher.osu.edu/supplements/10/2862/1962%20LBDQ%20MANUAL.pdf|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
== Consideration and Initiating structure == === Consideration === [[Consideration of future consequences|Consideration]] is the extent to which a leader exhibits concern for the welfare of the members of the [[Social group|group]].
This factor is oriented towards [[interpersonal relationships]], mutual [[Trust (emotion)|trust]] and [[friendship]].
This [[leadership style]] is people-oriented.
Some of the statements used to measure this factor in the LBDQ are: *being friendly *treating all group members as his/her equal *looking out for the personal [[welfare]] of group members *making him/herself accessible to group members
=== Initiating structure === Initiating Structure is the extent to which a leader defines leader and group member roles, initiates actions, organizes group activities and defines how tasks are to be accomplished by the group.
This leadership style is task-oriented.
Some of the statements used to measure this factor in the LBDQ are: *letting group members know what is expected of them *maintaining definite [[Job performance|standards of performance]] *scheduling the work to be done *checking that group members follow standard [[Business rule|rule]]s and [[regulations]]
==References== {{reflist}}
*Bass, B.M. (1990). ''Bass and Stogdill's Handbook of Leadership''. New York: Free Press. [https://books.google.com.sa/books/about/Bass_Stogdill_s_Handbook_of_Leadership.html?id=KxLizZ3aYmUC&redir_esc=y] *Farahbakhsh, S. "Leadership in Educational Administration: Concepts, Theories and Perspectives." ''Academic Leadership.'' 4(22). Retrieved on 2006-12-06.[http://www.academicleadership.org/volume4/issue1/articles/22/index.html] *Judge, T.A., Piccolo, R.F. and Ilies, R. (2004). "The Forgotten Ones? The Validity of Consideration and Initiating Structure in Leadership Research" ''Journal of Applied Psychology.'' 89(1) 36-51.[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/8881160_The_Forgotten_Ones_The_Validity_of_Consideration_and_Initiating_Structure_in_Leadership_Research] *Tracy, L. (1987). "Consideration and Initiating Structure: Are They Basic Dimensions of Leader Behavior?" ''Social Behavior and Personality.'' 15(1), 21-33. *[https://www.sbp-journal.com/index.php/sbp/article/view/522] Stogdill, R.M. (1963). ''Manual for the LBDQ-Form XII''. Columbus (OH): Bureau of Business Research of Ohio State University. *Stogdill, R.M. (1974). ''Handbook of leadership: A survey of theory and practice'', New York: Free Press.

[[File:Web C&C.png|6 Region C&C Gross and Per Capita|thumb|right|300px]] '''Contraction and Convergence''' (C&C) is a proposed global framework for reducing [[greenhouse gas]] emissions to combat [[climate change]]. Conceived by the [[Global Commons Institute]] [GCI] in the early 1990s, the Contraction and Convergence strategy consists of reducing overall emissions of greenhouse gases to a safe level (contraction), resulting from every country bringing its emissions [[per capita]] to a level which is equal for all countries (convergence). It is intended to form the basis of an international agreement which will reduce [[carbon dioxide]] emissions to [[Avoiding dangerous climate change|avoid dangerous climate change]], carbon dioxide being the gas that is primarily responsible for changes in the [[greenhouse effect]] on Earth. It is expressed as a simple mathematical formula. This formula can be used as a way for the world to stabilize carbon levels at any level. Advocates of Contraction and Convergence stress that negotiations at the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change [UNFCCC] are governed sequentially by the 'objective' of the UNFCCC [safe and stable GHG concentration in the global atmosphere] followed by its organising principles ['precaution' and 'equity']. C&C is widely cited and supported.<ref>http://www.gci.org.uk/SDa.html</ref>
The C&C calculus is now embedded in Domain Two of GCI's Carbon Budget Accounting Tool <ref>http://www.gci.org.uk/CBAT_AUBREY/CBAT/index.html#domain-2</ref>
==The C&C Proposal== The "convergence" part structures how the entitlements to emit carbon are shared between the countries or regions of the world. Initially entitlements would reflect current emissions, however subject to a negotiation of 'the rate of convergence' these initial entitlements will converge towards equal per capita entitlements across the planet. An early date of convergence will mean that countries with currently low per capita emissions (which as a rule are poorer countries) will see their entitlements rise while a late date for full convergence would risk curtailing poorer countries' chances of development.
Once convergence is reached then all countries entitlements would continue to fall, subject to the contraction-event required to be UNFCCC-compliant.
Some argue that the per capita focus risks giving an incentive to countries to increase their population to "earn" more entitlements. To answer this, the GCI put a 'population base-year' function in the model for users to choose and specify any date between 2000 and 2050 beyond which no further entitlements would result from population growth.
==Acceptable concentration levels== Both the basic concept of Contraction and Convergence and the specific formulas that the [[Global Commons Institute]] advocate can be adapted to both very moderate restrictions on carbon emissions through to much more drastic measures depending on what final level of greenhouse gases concentration is deemed to carry an acceptable level of risk. However, supporters of Contraction and Convergence believe that a safe level at which concentrations of greenhouse gases should stabilize is much lower than many suggest. Specifically they believe that suggestions that atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide of 550 parts per million by volume (ppmv) would be safe are wrong. This they consider runs the risk of entering a phase of runaway "climate feedback", where one change sparks off another with unpredictable results. They advocate erring on the side of caution, with atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide being stabilized at 350-450 ppmv. GCI's numerical analysis of the unrealistically optimistic 'sink-assumptions' behind the UK Climate Act is here <ref name="gci.org.uk">http://www.gci.org.uk/Documents/OrigStatement2.pdf</ref>
==History== The origin of GCI's intervention dates from 1989 and resulted in a statement published in 1990 in the Guardian June 18, 1991 <ref name="gci.org.uk"/>
The formal calculating model 'Contraction and Convergence' [C&C] was developed over a period of three years in response to the objective and principles of the [[UNFCCC]]. Between 1992 and 1995, at the request of the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]], GCI undertook and presented an analysis on the growing trends of expansion and divergence, which revealed the increasing asymmetry in global development between [[developed country|developed]] and [[developing country|developing]] countries — ultimately observing that it was developing countries that would be worst affected by climate change. C&C was developed by GCI to counteract the adverse effects of these trends.
==Application== The application of the framework begins with a full-term contraction [[budget]] for global emissions consistent with stabilising atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases at a pre-agreed concentration deemed to be safe. In order to help negotiators at the UNFCCC negotiations internationally share this emissions contraction-budget in a way that is less arbitrary and chaotic than it was under 'Kyoto', the C&C model will calculate any rate of linear convergence of all Parties to the global per capita average arising under the chosen contraction rate. This can be on year anywhere between immediate and 'end-of-term' with or without a population base-year as desired. As Prof Ross Garnaut has observed in his 'Review' for the Australian Government, "this rate-of-convergence is the main equity lever" in the negotiations. Practically it means that the sooner the convergence occurs, the faster the gap between under-consumers and over consumers is closed but within the agreed contraction budget. Quickly following the launch of the Garnaut Review, collaborating researchers at Monash University published the first empirical C&C target based on human life expectancies across nations. The paper called for early adoption of C&C to soften any impact on younger generations.<ref>Read, P, Stanley, J, Vella-Brodrick, D & Griggs, D (2013) Towards a contraction and convergence target based on population life expectancies since 1960. Environment, Development & Sustainability. October (2013) Vol 15(5) pp 1173-1187</ref>
==Support== In 2009 the Hadley Centre [UKMO] agreed that the rates of C&C projected by GCI to keep within 2 degrees Celsius were better than those projected by the UK Government in its 'Climate Act'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Second Memo from GCI to the UK House of Commons ‘Environmental Audit Committee’|url=http://www.gci.org.uk/Documents/GCI_EAC.pdf|accessdate=21 June 2012}}</ref>
In 2013 a further memo to the House of Commons Environmental Audit Committee presented a detailed critique of why the rates of C&C in the UK 'Climate Act' needed revision (acceleration) and provided a heuristic device (CBAT) to assist the understanding of this and how the revision might be organised.<ref>{{cite web|title= Further Memo from GCI to the UK House of Commons ‘Environmental Audit Committee’|url=http://www.gci.org.uk/Documents/EAC_Real_.pdf|accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref>
==C&C, COP-15 and COP-21== The C&C aspect of the negotiations at the [[2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP-15) in Copenhagen in 2009 provoked controversy.<ref name=COP-15>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessgreen.com/business-green/comment/2255920/copenhagen-blame-game-sparked |title=Copenhagen blame game sparked by failure to properly explain Danish Text |publisher=BusinessGreen |date=11 Jan 2010 |accessdate=2012-06-21}}</ref>
However, these animations of C&C as 'Climate Justice without Vengeance' show transparently the financial implications of negotiating an 'accelerated convergence' which issue remains directly relevant to achieving the 'global climate deal' still sought for at COP-16 and beyond.
The contraction aspect of C&C was demonstrated by the UK Government Special Representative for Climate Change [[Sir David King]] at a debriefing to the IEA on COP-21 in January 2016. This compared the contraction-rates needed for 1.5 °C & 2 °C, with the INDCs on offer in the 'Paris Agreement' at 'COP-21'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Presentation to IEA on COP-21 by Sir David King|url=http://www.gci.org.uk/images/INDCs_COP_21_a.pdf|accessdate=28 January 2016}}</ref>
The animation files referenced above are available as both *.swf file and flash-self-executable [for both Macs and PCs] and are stable and virus-free: -
http://www.gci.org.uk/animations/C&C_COP_15.exe http://www.tangentfilms.com/C&CPRESMAC.hqx

{{Infobox person | name = Daniel Shays | image = Daniel Shays (Shays' Rebellion).jpg | caption = "An Authentic Portrait of the Chief Insurgent" from 1878's "Our First Century" by Richard Miller Devens | birth_date = {{circa}}1747 | birth_place = [[Hopkinton, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{death date|1825|9|29}} | death_place = [[Sparta, New York]] | resting_place = Union Cemetery, Scottsburg, New York | occupation = farmer, military officer | known_for = [[American Revolutionary War]] Captain
[[Shays' Rebellion]] | networth = | spouse = Abigail Gilbert | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | website = | signature = DanielShays.svg |module={{Infobox military person|embed=yes |allegiance={{Flag|United States of America|1777}} |branch={{Flagicon image|New England blank flag.svg}} Massachusetts militia
{{Flagicon image|Gadsden flag.svg}} [[Continental Army]] |serviceyears=1775–1780 |rank=Captain |unit={{Flagicon image|New England blank flag.svg}} [[5th Massachusetts Regiment]] |battles=American Revolutionary War *[[Boston campaign]] **[[Battles of Lexington and Concord]] *[[Battles of Saratoga]] [[Shays' Rebellion]] }} }} '''Daniel Shays''' ({{circa|lk=no|1747}}{{spaced ndash}}September 29, 1825) was an American soldier, revolutionary, and farmer famous for being one of the leaders of [[Shays' Rebellion]], a populist uprising against controversial debt collection and tax policies in [[Massachusetts]] in 1786 and 1787. ==Early life== [[File:Daniel and Abigail Shays' Pelham, MA farmhouse.jpg|thumb|Daniel and Abigail Shays' Pelham, MA farmhouse, {{circa|lk=no|1898}}]] Daniel Shays was born in 1747 in [[Hopkinton, Massachusetts]], the son of Irish immigrants Patrick and Margaret (Dempsey) Shays. Daniel was the second of six; his siblings were Margaret, James, Roger, Phebe, and Mary Polly.The Family of Daniel Shays, from Descendants of Daniel Shays, by Elmer S. Smail, November, 1934: http://www.worldcat.org/title/family-of-daniel-shays-from-descendants-of-daniel-shays-by-elmer-s-smail-november-1934/oclc/17982816&referer=brief_results He spent his early years as a landless farm laborer. In 1772, he married Abigail Gilbert, and they settled in [[Brookfield, Massachusetts]]{{cite book|author=Brown, Lorri|chapter=Shays, Daniel (1747–1825)|editor=Danver Steven L.|title=Revolts, protests, demonstrations, and rebellions in American history: an encyclopedia|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2010|isbn=978-1-59884-221-0|page=220|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A1C4W2IVHcMC&pg=PA220}} where they had 6 children."Massachusetts Births and Christenings, 1639-1915," database, FamilySearch (https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:FC3N-TJR : 4 December 2014), Daniel Shayes in entry for Daniel Shayes, 31 Jan 1773; citing, Shutesbury, Franklin, Massachusetts, 2:179B4K1; FHL microfilm 886,455 ==Revolutionary War== Shays joined the local militia during the American Revolution and rose to the rank of captain in the [[5th Massachusetts Regiment]] of the Continental Army by 1777. He was involved in the [[Boston campaign]] and fought at the [[Battle of Bunker Hill]].Richards, pf u. 95 He also fought in the [[Battle of Lexington]] and the [[Battle of Saratoga]]. He was wounded during the war and resigned from the military unpaid in 1780. Upon returning home, he was summoned to court for unpaid debts, which he could not pay because he had not been paid in full for his military service.Zinn, pp. 71–72[https://archive.org/stream/massachusettssol14mass#page/76/mode/2up Massachusetts Solder and Sailors in the war of the Revolution Vol XIV p.76 summary of Shays service record] In 1780, [[General Lafayette]] presented him with an ornamental sword in honor of his military service. He later sold it for a few dollars to help pay off his debts, which was frowned upon by his peers.{{cite book|author=Gross, Robert A.|chapter=The Uninvited Guest: Daniel Shays and the Constitution|editor=Gross, Robert A.|title=In Debt to Shays: The Bicentennial of an Agrarian Rebellion|publisher=University Press of Virginia|year=1993|isbn=978-0-8139-1354-4|page=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HpSIYclyYogC&pg=PA1}} ==Shays' Rebellion== [[File:Daniel Shays and Job Shattuck.jpg|thumb|275px|right|Contemporary engraving depicting Daniel Shays (left) and [[Job Shattuck]], another rebel leader; the artist intentionally rendered them in an unflattering way]] {{Main article|Shays' Rebellion}} ===Debt and tax burdens=== After returning from the war, Daniel Shays was alarmed to discover that many of his fellow veterans and farmers were in the same financial situation as he. At commoners' meetings veterans asserted that they were treated unfairly upon release, and that businessmen were trying to squeeze money out of smallholders in order to pay their own debts to European war investors. Many Massachusetts rural communities first tried to petition the legislature in Boston,Zinn, pp. 91–93 but the legislature was dominated by eastern merchant interests and did not respond substantively to those petitions. The petitions and proposals often included a request to issue paper currency. Such inflationary issues would depreciate the currency, making it possible to meet obligations made at high values with lower-valued paper. The merchants, among them [[James Bowdoin]], were opposed to these proposals because they were generally lenders who stood to lose. These proposals were repeatedly rejected.Szatmary, pp. 38–42, 45 Governor [[John Hancock]], accused by some of anticipating trouble, abruptly resigned in early 1785. When Bowdoin (a loser to Hancock in earlier elections) was elected governor that year, matters became more severe. Bowdoin stepped up civil actions to collect back taxes, and the legislature exacerbated the situation by levying an additional property tax to raise funds for the state's portion of foreign debt payments.Richards, pp. 87–88 Even comparatively conservative commentators like [[John Adams]] observed that these levies were "heavier than the People could bear".Richards, p. 88 ===Protests against the courts=== Protests in the rural Massachusetts turned into [[direct action]] in August 1786, after the state legislature adjourned without considering the many petitions that had been sent to Boston.Richards, pp. 6–9Szatmary, p. 38 On August 29 a well-organized force of protestors, Shays among them, marched on [[Northampton, Massachusetts|Northampton]] and successfully prevented the county court from sitting.Morse, p. 208 The leaders of this and later forces proclaimed that they were seeking relief from the burdensome judicial processes that were depriving the people of their land and possessions. They called themselves ''Regulators'', a reference to the [[Regulator movement]] of [[North Carolina]] that sought to reform corrupt practices in the late 1760s.Szatmary, p. 56 On September 2 Governor Bowdoin issued a proclamation denouncing such mob action, but took no military measures in response beyond planning militia response to future actions.Szatmary, pp. 79–80 When the court in [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]] was shut down by similar action on September 5, the county militia (composed mainly of men sympathetic to the protestors) refused to turn out, much to Bowdoin's amazement.Szatmary, p. 80 Shays, who had participated in the Northampton action, began to take a more active leadership role in the uprising in November. On September 19, the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court|Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts]] indicted eleven leaders of the rebellion as "disorderly, riotous, and seditious persons."Zinn, p. 93 When the supreme judicial court was next scheduled to meet in [[Springfield, Massachusetts|Springfield]] on September 26, Shays in [[Hampshire County, Massachusetts|Hampshire County]] and [[Luke Day]] in what is now [[Hampden County, Massachusetts|Hampden County]] (but was then part of Hampshire County) organized an attempt to shut it down. They were anticipated by [[William Shepard]], the local militia commander, who began gathering government-supporting militia the Saturday before the court was to sit. By the time the court was ready to open, Shepard had 300 men protecting the Springfield courthouse. Shays and Day were able to recruit a similar number, but chose only to demonstrate, exercising their troops outside Shepard's lines, rather than attempt to seize the building.Holland, pp. 245–47 The judges first postponed the hearings, and then adjourned on the 28th without hearing any cases. Shepard withdrew his force, which had grown to some 800 men (to the Regulators' 1,200), to the [[Springfield Armory|federal armory]], which was then only rumored to be the target of seizure by the activists.Holland, p. 247 ===Plan to seize the Springfield Armory=== On November 28 a posse of some 300 men rode to [[Groton, Massachusetts|Groton]] to arrest [[Job Shattuck]] and other protest leaders in the area. Shattuck was chased down and arrested on the 30th, and was wounded by a sword slash in the process.Szatmary, pp. 92–93 This action and the arrest of other protest leaders in the eastern parts of the state radicalized those in the west, and they began to organize an overthrow of the state government. "The seeds of war are now sown", wrote one correspondent in [[Shrewsbury, Massachusetts|Shrewsbury]],Szatmary, p. 94 and by mid-January rebel leaders spoke of smashing the "tyrannical government of Massachusetts."Szatmary, p. 97 While government forces organized in the east, Shays, Day, and other rebel leaders in the west organized their forces, establishing regional regimental organizations that were run by democratically elected committees. Their first major target was the federal armory in Springfield.Szatmary, pp. 98–99 General Shepard had, however, pursuant to orders from Governor Bowdoin, taken possession of the armory and used its arsenal to arm a force of some 1,200 militia.Richards, pp. 27–28Holland, p. 261 ===Attack and collapse=== The insurgents were organized into three major groups, and intended to surround and simultaneously attack the armory. Shays led one group east of Springfield near [[Palmer, Massachusetts|Palmer]], Luke Day had a second force across the Connecticut River in [[West Springfield, Massachusetts|West Springfield]], and the third force, under [[Eli Parsons]], was to the north at [[Chicopee, Massachusetts|Chicopee]].Richards, p. 28 The rebels had planned their assault for January 25, but Luke Day changed this at the last minute, sending Shays a message indicating he would not be ready to attack until the 26th.Szatmary, p. 101 Day's message was intercepted by Shepard's men, so the militia of Shays and Parsons, some 1,500 men, approached the armory on the 25th not knowing they would have no support from the west.Richards, p. 29 [[Image:Springfield Armory.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Springfield Armory]] (building pictured is from the 19th century) was the first major target of the rebellion.]] When Shays and his forces neared the armory, they found Shepard's militia waiting for them. Shepard first ordered warning shots fired over the approaching Shaysites' heads, and then ordered two cannons to fire [[grape shot]] at Shays's men. Four Shaysites were killed and twenty wounded. There was no musket fire from either side, and the rebel advance collapsed.Szatmary, p. 102 Most of the rebel force fled north, eventually regrouping at [[Amherst, Massachusetts|Amherst]]. On the opposite side of the river, Day's forces also fled north, also eventually reaching Amherst.Szatmary, p. 103 General [[Benjamin Lincoln]] had mustered 3,000 men at [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]] to deal with the rebels. When he heard of the Springfield incident, they immediately began marching west. Shays led the rebel force generally north and east to avoid Lincoln, eventually establishing a camp at [[Petersham, Massachusetts|Petersham]]; along the way they raided the shops of local merchants for supplies, taking some of them hostage. Lincoln pursued them, reaching [[Pelham, Massachusetts|Pelham]], some {{convert|10|mi|km}} from Petersham, on February 2.Szatmary, pp. 103–04 On the night of February 3–4, he led his militia on a forced march to Petersham through a bitter snowstorm. Arriving early in the morning, they surprised the rebel camp so thoroughly that they scattered "without time to call in their out parties or even their guards."Szatmary, p. 105 Although Lincoln claimed to capture 150 men, none of them were officers, leading historian Leonard Richards to suspect the veracity of the report. Shays and some of the other leaders escaped north into New Hampshire and Vermont.Richards, pp. 31, 120 Some four thousand people signed confessions acknowledging participation in the events of the rebellion (in exchange for amnesty); several hundred participants were eventually indicted on charges relating to the rebellion. Most of these were pardoned under a general amnesty that only excluded a few ringleaders. Eighteen men, including Shays, were convicted and sentenced to death. Most of these were either overturned on appeal, pardoned, or had their sentences commuted. Two of the condemned men, John Bly and Charles Rose, were hanged on December 6, 1787.Richards, pp. 38–41 Shays was pardoned in 1788 and he returned to Massachusetts from hiding in the Vermont woods.Zinn, p. 95 He was, however, vilified by the Boston press, who painted him as an archetypal anarchist opposed to the government.Richards, p. 117 ==Later life== Shays was later granted a pension by the federal government for the five years he served in the [[Continental Army]] without pay. Shays lived the last few years of his life in poverty, a heavy drinker. He supported himself on his pension and by working a small parcel of land.{{cite book|author=Gross, Robert A.|chapter=The Uninvited Guest: Daniel Shays and the Constitution|editor=Gross, Robert A.|title=In Debt to Shays: The Bicentennial of an Agrarian Rebellion|publisher=University Press of Virginia|year=1993|isbn=978-0-8139-1354-4|page=2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HpSIYclyYogC&pg=PA2}} Shays died at age 78 in [[Sparta, New York]], and was buried at the Union Cemetery in [[Scottsburg, New York|Scottsburg]].{{cite web |url=http://nyhistoric.com/2011/10/captain-daniel-shays/ |title=Captain Daniel Shays |website=nyhistoric.com/ |publisher=New York Historic |access-date=August 13, 2016}} ==Rededicated grave marker== The original gravestone for Shays contained an error; by dropping the "s", Shays was incorrectly spelled as "Shay".{{cite news |last=Beagle |first=Ben |date=August 7, 2016 |title=Gravestone Rededication: Heroic rebel, formative figure in U.S. history, to gets his ‘S’ |url=http://www.thelcn.com/lcn01/gravestone-rededication-heroic-rebel-formative-figure-in-us-history-to-gets-his-s-20160807 |newspaper=Livingston County News |location=Geneseo, NY }} In 2016, Philip R. Shays, of [[Clarence Center, New York]], a descendant of Daniel Shays, led an effort to correct the error. Because the original stone did not contain enough space to add a letter, a new marker was created."[http://www.thelcn.com/lcn01/gravestone-rededication-heroic-rebel-formative-figure-in-us-history-to-gets-his-s-20160807 Gravestone Rededication: Heroic rebel, formative figure in U.S. history, to gets his ‘S’]" The new gravestone was dedicated in a ceremony on August 12.{{cite news |date=August 12, 2016 |title=Revolutionary War hero gets new headstone – with his name spelled correctly |url=http://13wham.com/news/local/revolutionary-war-hero-gets-new-headstone-with-his-name-spelled-correctly |newspaper=WHAM-TV |location=Rochester, NY}} File:ShaysGraveDedicationsAug2016.jpg|Dedication ceremony for new Daniel Shays gravestone File:ShaysGravestoneSide A.jpg|Front side of rededicated gravestone for Daniel Shays File:ShaysGravestoneSide B.jpg|Reverse side of new gravestone for Daniel Shays ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==Sources== * {{cite book|last=Holland|first=Josiah Gilbert|title=History of Western Massachusetts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aiBMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA245#v=onepage&f=false|publisher=S.
