[[Diederik Samsom]] (2012) | election = [[Dutch general election, 2010|2010 election]] | last_election = [[Dutch general election, 2012|2012 election]] | legislature_term = [[List of members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, 2010–12|2010–2012]] | incoming_formation = [[2010 Dutch cabinet formation|2010 formation]] | outgoing_formation = [[2012 Dutch cabinet formation|2012 formation]] | previous = [[Fourth Balkenende cabinet]] | successor = [[Second Rutte cabinet]] | state_head_title = Monarch | government_head_title = Prime Minister | deputy_government_head_title = Deputy Prime Minister }} {{Politics of the Netherlands}} The '''First Rutte cabinet''', also called the '''Rutte–Verhagen cabinet''' was the [[cabinet of the Netherlands]] from 14 October 2010 until 5 November 2012. The cabinet was formed by the [[List of political parties in the Netherlands|political parties]] [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (VVD) and the [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] (CDA) after the [[Dutch general election, 2010|election of 2010]]. The [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] cabinet was a [[minority government]] in the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] but was [[Confidence and supply|supported]] by the [[Party for Freedom]] (PVV) for a majority. It was the first of three cabinets of [[Mark Rutte]], the [[Leader of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] as [[Prime Minister of the Netherlands|Prime Minister]], with [[Maxime Verhagen]] the [[Leader of the Christian Democratic Appeal]] serving as [[Deputy Prime Minister of the Netherlands|Deputy Prime Minister]]. ==Formation== {{main|2010 Dutch cabinet formation}} Following the collapse of the fourth Balkenende cabinet on 20 February 2010, elections for the House of Representatives were held on 9 June 2010. As usual in Dutch politics, none of the parties had a majority and several ''[[Informateur]]s'' were appointed to investigate the formation of a coalition cabinet. A broad coalition consisting of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]], [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] and the [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour Party]] was briefly looked at, but dismissed. Then negotiations for a "[[Purple (government)|purple plus]]" coalition consisting of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]], [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour Party]], [[Democrats 66]] and [[GroenLinks|GreenLeft]] lasted for about three weeks, but the parties could not reach agreement on the amount of budget cuts. Finally, a construction which is rare for the Netherlands was investigated: a minority coalition consisting of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] and [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] (together 52 out of 150 seats in the House of Representatives), supported in parliament by the [[Party for Freedom]] (24 seats), to make the smallest possible majority of 76 seats. The reason for this construction was that parties agreed that the largest party the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] and the largest winner in the elections needed to be in power; only the [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] could or wanted to help make a majority, but they were against forming a proper coalition with [[Party for Freedom]] because of their different views on Islam and immigration. Therefore, negotiations were held to form a coalition agreement between the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] and [[Christian Democratic Appeal]], and to form a "parliamentary support agreement" between all three parties, which were successfully finished on 30 September 2010. When Rutte took office on 14 October, it marked the first time that the VVD had led a government since its formation in 1946. It also marked the first [[liberalism in the Netherlands|liberal]]-led government since 1913. The opposition parties expected that the coalition would prove to be unstable because at a special [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] conference, about a third of the [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] members voted against the formation of this cabinet. Also, in the [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] parliamentary fraction at least two people indicated they have difficulties with the cabinet, but say they will support it because the majority of the party approves of the cabinet. When the cabinet took office, the three parties had a minority in the [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]] of 35 out of 75 seats. The parties hoped this would change following the [[Dutch Senate election, 2011|Dutch Senate election of 2011]], but they obtained 37 seats, one short of a majority. However, it is expected that the small Christian party [[Reformed Political Party]], which obtained one seat, will support the cabinet in the Senate. The cabinet consisted of 12 [[Minister (government)|Ministers]] and 8 [[Secretary of State|State secretaries]]. The positions where divided equally among the coalition members, regardless of their respective size: [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (31 seats in parliament) supplied 6 Ministers and 4 State secretaries, and [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] (21 seats) also supplied 6 Ministers and 4 State secretaries. [[File:Rutte-Clegg.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Prime Minister [[Mark Rutte]] and [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[Nick Clegg]] in the [[Torentje]] on 15 November 2010.]] [[File:Teeven Napolitano.jpg|thumb|right|250px|State Secretary for Security and Justice [[Fred Teeven]] and [[United States Secretary of Homeland Security]] [[Janet Napolitano]] in [[The Hague]] on 22 June 2011.]] [[File:Rutte and Nguyen Tan Dung 3.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Prime Minister [[Mark Rutte]] and [[Prime Minister of Vietnam]] [[Nguyễn Tấn Dũng]] at the [[Binnenhof]] on 28 September 2011.]] [[File:Ontmoeting Poetin (6266065156).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Prime Minister [[Mark Rutte]] and [[Prime Minister of Russia]] [[Vladimir Putin]] in the [[White House (Moscow)|White House]] on 20 October 2011.]] [[File:Mark Rutte Barack Obama.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Prime Minister [[Mark Rutte]] and [[President of the United States]] [[Barack Obama]] in the [[Oval Office]] on 29 November 2011.]] [[File:Persconferentie Rutte en Di Rupo (6720520991).jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Prime Minister of Belgium]] [[Elio Di Rupo]] and Prime Minister [[Mark Rutte]] at a press conference in the [[Catshuis]] on 18 January 2012.]] ==Term== ===Policy=== In accordance with the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] approach to ''[[laissez-faire]]'' and a [[small government]] the number of ministers and State Secretaries was reduced from the previous cabinet by merging several ministries. The [[Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality]] was merged with the Ministry of Economic Affairs to vorm a combined [[Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy (Netherlands)|Ministry Economic Affairs, Agriculture and Innovation]]. The [[Ministry of Housing, Spatial Planning and the Environment (Netherlands)|Ministry of Housing, Spatial Planning and the Environment]] was merged with the [[Ministry of Transport and Water Management (Netherlands)|Ministry of Transport and Water Management]] to form the new [[Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management|Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment]]. Also the portfolio of [[Public security]] was transferred from the [[Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]] to the Ministry of Justice which was renamed as the [[Ministry of Justice and Security|Ministry of Security and Justice]]. Also the position of the [[Minister for Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation (Netherlands)|Minister for Development Cooperation]], a long serving [[Minister without portfolio]] title that had been used continuously since 1965 except for a small break from 2002 until 2003 was scrapped and replaced by the return of a [[Minister without portfolio]] for Immigration and Asylum Affairs like in the previous [[First Balkenende cabinet|Cabinets Balkenende I]], [[Second Balkenende cabinet|II]] and [[Third Balkenende cabinet|III]], but this time the [[Minister without portfolio]] for Immigration and Asylum Affairs was placed in the jurisdiction of the [[Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]] instead of the [[Ministry of Justice and Security|Ministry of Security and Justice]]. ===Withdrawal of support of the Party for Freedom=== Because of the financial crisis in the Netherlands and because of the rules of the [[Euro convergence criteria]] that the deficit should be maximum 3%, the [[Party leader|Leaders]] of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] [[Mark Rutte]], [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] [[Maxime Verhagen]] and the [[Party for Freedom]] [[Geert Wilders]] decided to talk with each other about new, severe austerity measures, worth about 14 billion Euro. The negotiations about the measures were held in the [[Catshuis]] and lasted 7 weeks and ended on 21 April when Geert Wilders walked out of the negotiations. The reason he gave was that the measure would negatively impact people who receive benefits from the [[Algemene Ouderdomswet|pensions law]]. Both Mark Rutte and Maxime Verhagen blamed Wilders for the failure of the negotiations. As a result, the government resigned and a new election was called. ===Composition Changes=== On 16 December 2011 [[List of Ministers of the Interior of the Netherlands|Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]] [[Piet Hein Donner]] (CDA) resigned after he was nominated as the new [[Vice-President of the Council of State (Netherlands)|Vice-President of the Council of State]] succeeding [[Herman Tjeenk Willink]]. He was replaced as [[List of Ministers of the Interior of the Netherlands|Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]] by former [[Christian Democratic Appeal|Chairwoman of the Christian Democratic Appeal]] [[Liesbeth Spies]]. [[Piet Hein Donner]] as [[List of Ministers of the Interior of the Netherlands|Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]] was responsible for the portfolio of Integration. When he resigned the Integration portfolio was transferred to [[Minister without portfolio]] [[Gerd Leers]].{{nl icon}} [http://nos.nl/artikel/322712-benoeming-spies-tot-minister-verwacht.html Benoeming Spies tot minister vrijdag verwacht], NOS, 15 December 2011{{nl icon}} [http://nos.nl/artikel/322863-donner-naar-raad-van-state.html Donner naar Raad van State], NOS, 16 December 2011{{nl icon}} [http://www.nu.nl/politiek/2694905/spies-volgt-donner-in-kabinet.html 'Spies volgt Donner op in kabinet'], NU.nl, 16 December 2011 ==Cabinet Members== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !colspan=3|[[Minister (government)|Ministers]] !colspan=2|Title/[[Ministries of the Netherlands|Ministry]] !Term of office !Party |- | style="background:{{People's Party for Freedom and Democracy/meta/color}};"| | [[File:Mark-rutte-portret.jpg|120px|Mark Rutte]] | [[Mark Rutte]]

page.title: Fundamental rights in the German Constitution

revision.text:
[[File:JKH-19 Artikel.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Grundrechte at Jakob Kaiser House, [[Berlin]]]]
'''Fundamental Rights in the [[Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]]''' (''German: Grundrechte'') are a set of rights guaranteed to everyone in Germany and partially to German people only through their [[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany|Federal Constitution, the ''Grundgesetz'']] and the constitutions of some of the [[States of Germany]]. In the Federal Constitution, the majority of the ''Grundrechte'' are contained in the first title, Articles 1 to 19 of the Grundgesetz (GG). These rights have constitutional status, binding each of the country's [[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany#Constitutional institutions|constitutional institutions]]. In the event that these rights are violated and a remedy is denied by [[Judiciary of Germany|other courts]], the constitution provides for an appeal to the [[Federal Constitutional Court of Germany|Federal Constitutional Court]] (''Bundesverfassungsgericht'') (Art. 93 (1) (4a) GG).
According to this article, the Constitutional Court is entitled to hear appeals concerning not just the ''Grundrechte'' contained in Arts. 1-19, but also Arts. 20 (4), 33, 38, 101, 103 and 104. These rights are also therefore referred to as ''grundrechtsgleiche Rechte'' (rights equal to fundamental rights) or colloquially also as fundamental rights.
==Limitation== In addition to the ''Grundrechte'', the Constitution guarantees a number of other public rights, such as the uniform application of federal law between states (Art.28 (2)(1) GG) and the independence of the church (Art. 137 (3) of the Weimar Constitution and Art. 140 GG). These however are not ''Grundrechte'' as they are not contained under the first title of the constitution or in the appeal mechanism to the Federal Constitutional Court.
There are also lists of fundamental rights in the majority of state constitutions, which vary slightly from one another but are never capable of ruling out a ''Grundrecht''. ''Landesrechte'' (i.e. rights guaranteed by state constitutions) which mirror ''Bundesrechte'' (those guaranteed by the Federal Constitution) are therefore disregarded in favour of the ''Bundesrechte''. Many state constitutions which were written after the Federal Constitution do not contain their own lists of fundamental rights at all.
==Applicability== All the ''Grundrechte'' have a binding effect on each of the constitutional institutions, regardless of whether it is the [[Cabinet of Germany|executive]], [[Bundestag|legislature]] or [[Judiciary of Germany|judiciary]], federally or in one of the states (''Länder''). It is also irrelevant whether the state was directly or indirectly involved in the violation, whether it acted through public or private law or through legal entities under private law; public bodies are always bound by the ''Grundrechte'' (Art. 1(3) GG).
Rights under the German constitution can also be divided between universal fundamental rights (''Jedermann-Grundrechte''), which are afforded to everyone, and German fundamental rights (''Deutschengrundrechte, Staatsbürgerrechte'' or ''Deutschenrechte''), to which only Germans are entitled. The reason for the separation is largely due to democratic will and the protection of sovereignty.
The ''Deutschengrundrechte'' include the rights to [[freedom of assembly]] (Art. 8 GG), [[freedom of association]] (Art. 9 GG), [[Right of abode|freedom of abode]] (Art. 11 GG) and [[right to work|freedom to work]] (Art. 12 GG), as well as the right to vote and stand for public office. The restriction of these rights only to Germans does not just refer to German citizenship, [[German nationality law|German status]] being regulated by Art. 116 GG. While some ''Grundrechte'' apply only to Germans, there are some on which only non-Germans can rely, e.g. right to asylum (art. 16a GG).
Some of the ''Deutschengrundrechte'' also apply for other [[Citizenship of the European Union|citizens of the European Union]] with or without residence in Germany regarding their rights to move freely within Germany or to work. Nevertheless it is disputed whether all German fundamental rights apply to them in light of the prohibition of discrimination contained in Art. 18 (1) of the [[Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union|TFEU treaty]]. This article requires that all citizens of the EU are given equal status and equality of protection under all legal systems in the community.
According to their contents, the ''Grundrechte'' can also be divided into freedom rights and equality rights.
==Protection== Although the Grundgesetz might be changed with a 2/3 majority of the Bundestag, the original Fundamental Rights are protected by article 19. Modification on the first 18 articles is only allowed as long as the essential contents remain unchanged.
==External links== *[http://germanlawarchive.iuscomp.org/?p=212 English translation of the German Constitution]

{{Lead too short|date=April 2017}} {{Morereferences|date=April 2017}} Identity-based security is an approach to control access to a digital product or service based on the authenticated identity of an individual. This allows organizations to grant access to specific users to access a variety of digital services using the same credentials, ensuring the accurate match between what users are entitled to and what they actually receive,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.10duke.com/file/whitepapers/10Duke-Whitepaper-Pillars_for_effective_Personalisation.pdf |format=PDF |title=Identity and Access Management: Pillars for effective Personalisation |publisher=''10duke.com'' |date=2016-02-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705065947/http://www.10duke.com/file/whitepapers/10Duke-Whitepaper-Pillars_for_effective_Personalisation.pdf |archivedate=2017-07-05 |accessdate=2017-11-14 }}</ref> while also permitting other access constraints such as company, device, location and application type ([[Attribute-based access control|attributes]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gigaom.com/report/identity-based-security-and-the-cloud/ |title= Analyst Report: Identity-based security and the cloud |last=Linthicum |first=David |publisher=[[Gigaom]] |date=2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624051107/https://gigaom.com/report/identity-based-security-and-the-cloud/ |archivedate=2016-06-24 |accessdate=2017-11-14 }}</ref> Underpinning the identity-based security approach is the Identity-Based Access Control (IBAC),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://csrc.nist.gov/Glossary/?term=4708 |title=Glossary: Identity-Based Access Control |work=Computer Security Resource Center |publisher=[[NIST]] |accessdate=2017-11-14 }}</ref> (or identity-based licensing<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.10duke.com/resources/blog/2016-02-02:What_is_identity-based_licensing%3F.html |title=What is identity-based licensing? |publisher=''10duke.com'' |date=2016-02-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114103751/http://www.10duke.com/resources/blog/2016-02-02:What_is_identity-based_licensing%3F.html |archivedate=2017-11-14 |accessdate=2017-11-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.adobe.com/en_US/fmrms/1.0.1/overview.pdf#G4.1520496 |format=PDF |title=Adobe Flash Media Rights Management Server 1.0 Overview for Microsoft Windows, Linux, and UNIX |authorlink=Adobe Systems |work=Workflows - Identity-based licensing |publisher=[[Adobe Systems]] |date=2008-05-01 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829230756/https://help.adobe.com/en_US/fmrms/1.0.1/overview.pdf |archivedate=2017-08-29 |accessdate=2017-11-14 }}</ref>) concept.
[[NIST]] defines identity-based security policies as policies "based on the identities and/or attributes of the object (system resource) being accessed and of the subject (user, group of users, process, or device) requesting access."<ref>[http://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-33.pdf SP 800-33 - Underlying Technical Models for Information Technology Security], Gary Stoneburner, p. 21, December 2001, ''NIST Computer Security Publications - NIST Special Publications (SPs)'', [[doi:10.6028/NIST.SP.800-33]]. Retrieved 4 April 2017.</ref>
Some of the advantages of the identity-based security approach include the ability to exercise very fine-grained control over who is allowed to use which services and which functions those users can perform,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=102217 |title=.NET Identity and Principal Objects |last=Enrico |first=Sabbadin |work=informIT |publisher=[[Pearson Education]] |date=2003-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114114047/http://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=102217 |archivedate=2017-11-14 |accessdate=2017-11-14 }}</ref> and that it is device-agnostic, offering the possibility to enforce access control policy across a variety of devices, such as smartphones, tablets, and PCs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://esj.com/Articles/2012/07/16/BYOD-and-Identity-Based-Security.aspx?Page=2 |title=Q&A: Addressing BYOD with Identity-Based Security |last=Powell |first=James E. |publisher=Enterprise Systems Journal |date=2012-07-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114113119/https://esj.com/articles/2012/07/16/byod-and-identity-based-security.aspx |archivedate=2017-11-14 |accessdate=2017-11-14 }}</ref>
== Identity-based security models ==
=== Cyberoam’s approach ===
The identity-based security network security approach put forward by [[Cyberoam]] includes security components that provides visibility and control over user activity in a particular [[Computer network|network]]. It offers a network security system which includes a user's [[identity management|human identity]] as a part of the [[firewall (computer)|firewall]] rule matching criteria.<ref>[http://www.cyberoam.com/downloads/Whitepaper/CyberoamLayer8Technology.pdf Identity based security], ''cyberoam.com''.</ref>
The concept includes treating a user's identity as the 8th Layer (also known as the human layer{{cn|date=November 2017}}) in the [[Protocol_stack|network protocol stack]], thus attaching user identity to security while authenticating, authorizing and auditing the network. This takes a different step from conventional security appliances, which bind security to [[IP address|IP-address]]es. Such an approach allows organisations to create [[computer security policy|security policies]] that align to users and groups rather than to IP addresses which ultimately gives them more precise control over who can access the network—and what they can access.<ref>[http://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/products/collateral/routers/800-series-routers/at_a_glance_c45-675579.pdf Identity-Based Firewall Security], ''cisco.com''.</ref>
Identity-based security prevents systems against address [[IP address spoofing|spoofing]] attacks by combining the point of [[encryption]], [[authentication]], and [[access control]] into a single unit.<ref>[http://www.arubanetworks.com/pdf/solutions/identity-based-security.pdf Identity-Based Security], ''arubanetworks.com''</ref>

Kāpēc tā?|date=2 January 2018 |accessdate=1 July 2018|publisher=LSM.lv|language=lv}} | national = [[Union of Greens and Farmers]] | international = ''None'' | european = ''None'' | europarl = [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group|Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe]]{{cite news |url=http://www.lsm.lv/en/article/politics/liberals-and-democrats-adopt-latvias-stray-mep.a127286/ |title=Liberals and Democrats adopt Latvia’s stray MEP |date=April 25, 2015 |publisher=[[Public Broadcasting of Latvia]] |accessdate=April 28, 2015}} | seats1_title = [[Saeima]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|9|100|hex=#D1E231}} | seats2_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|1|9|hex=#D1E231}} | colours = [[Green]], [[White]] | headquarters = [[Riga]] | website = {{URL|www.lzs.lv}} }} The '''Latvian Farmers' Union''' ({{lang-lv|Latvijas Zemnieku savienība}}{{Cite web|url=http://lzs.lv/par-mums|title=Latvijas Zemnieku savienības programma (Programme of the Latvian Farmers' Union)|last=|first=|date=2018-03-24|website=lzs.lv|language=lv|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-11}}, LZS) is a [[Centrism|centrist]] and [[agrarianism|agrarian]] [[List of political parties in Latvia|political party]] in [[Latvia]]. ==History== Founded in 1917, the party was the most influential [[conservative]] party in Latvia in the period from [[Latvian War of Independence|Independence]] in 1918 until the [[self-coup]] [[1934 Latvian coup d'état|led by Kārlis Ulmanis in 1934]], and the second most popular party overall after the [[Latvian Social Democratic Workers' Party]]. [[Kārlis Ulmanis|Ulmanis]], who was a member of the party, banned all political parties after his coup including the LZS. As Latvia was subsequently [[Occupations of Latvia|occupied]] during the course of the [[Second World War]], the party was dormant until it reformed in 1990 when [[On the Restoration of Independence of the Republic of Latvia|Latvia regained its independence]]. Immediately after the restoration of independence, there existed several groups competing at elections to claim the legacy of the pre-war LZS. Since 2002 it has been part of the [[Union of Greens and Farmers]] (''ZZS'') coalition, along with the [[Latvian Green Party]]. The coalition now includes [[For Latvia and Ventspils]] and the [[Liepāja Party]], who have cooperation agreements with the party allowing their members to be elected to the [[Saeima]] on the list of the Union of Greens and Farmers. The coalition faction is currently the third largest in the Saeima and the LZS has 9 out of the 21 seats it holds. Since [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Latvia)|May 2014]] the party has had one [[member of the European Parliament]], [[Iveta Grigule]], who sits with the [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group|Alliance of Liberals and Democrats]] group, having previously sat with the [[Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy]] group and as a [[Non-Inscrits|Non-Attached Member]]. ==Election results== ===Parliament (''Saeima'')=== {| class=wikitable |- ! '''MuckRock''' is a United States-based 501(c)(3) non-profit organization which assists anyone in filing governmental requests for information through the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]], then publishes the returned information on its website and encourages journalism around it.
==History== MuckRock was founded by Michael Morisy and Mitchell Kotler, graduates of [[Cornell University]].<ref>[https://freedom.press/about/blogger/michael-morisy Michael Morisy], Freedom of the Press Foundation, Retrieved 28 December 2014</ref> The site's beta version went online in May 2010, and was part of the ''[[Boston Globe]]''’s GlobeLab incubator program.<ref>[http://cjr.org/behind_the_news/qa_michael_morisy_cofounder_of_muckrock.php Q&A: Michael Morisy, Co-Founder of MuckRock], ''Columbia Journalism Review'', 13 February 2012, Retrieved 28 December 2014</ref> MuckRock was granted a 501(c)(3) non-profit status by the [[IRS]] in June 2016.<ref>[https://www.muckrock.com/news/archives/2016/jun/15/muckrock-granted-501c3-non-profit-status/ MuckRock granted non-profit status], MuckRock, Retrieved 14 December 2017</ref> On June 11, 2018, MuckRock announced they would be merging with [[DocumentCloud]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.muckrock.com/news/archives/2018/jun/11/muckrock-documentcloud-merge-announcement/ |title=MuckRock and DocumentCloud merge to build tools for a more informed society |last=Morisy |first=Michael |last2=Pilhofer |first2=Aron |date=June 11, 2018 |website=Muckrock.org |publisher=MuckRock |access-date=June 11, 2018 |quote= We are thrilled to announce that DocumentCloud and MuckRock are merging.}}</ref>
==Operation== Filing requests for information through the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] has been described as confusing and tedious, despite the intent that the process be public and the service available to all American citizens.<ref name="Faraone">{{cite web |url= http://thephoenix.com/boston/news/111660-muckrock-city/ |title=MuckRock City - Media -- Dont Quote Me |first=Chris |last=Faraone |work=[[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Phoenix]] |date=17 November 2010 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref> MuckRock partially automates the process with an interface designed to make the filing of requests easier.<ref name="Faraone"/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2010/12/muckrock-automates-government-records.html |title=MuckRock automates government records requests - Boston Business Journal |first=Lynette F. |last=Cornell |work=bizjournals.com |date=6 December 2010 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://bostinno.streetwise.co/2010/12/02/a-%e2%80%9clegal-wikileaks%e2%80%9d-competing-in-knight-news-challenge |title=A "Legal WikiLeaks" Competing in Knight News Challenge |first=Maggie |last=Georgieva |work=[[BostInno]] |date=2 December 2010 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref> Also, MuckRock acts as a middleman for processing the requests, so when a user makes a request through MuckRock, it is the staff of MuckRock who themselves make the request.<ref name="Ellis">{{cite web |url= http://www.niemanlab.org/2010/10/muckrock-makes-foia-requests-easy-but-will-reporters-use-it/ |title=MuckRock makes FOIA requests easy, but will reporters use it? |first=Justin |last=Ellis |work=niemanlab.org |publisher=[[Nieman Foundation for Journalism]] |date=21 October 2010 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref> When MuckRock makes the request, they note and timestamp it on their website as proof of it being made.<ref name="Ellis"/> When a reply comes to the request, MuckRock publishes and timestamps it openly so that everyone can see the reply and when it was made.<ref name="Ellis"/>
==Information shared== In 2010 MuckRock received a notice that the government had sent MuckRock information about the [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program]] which was secret and that MuckRock must cease publishing it or its staff would face fines and jail time.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/11/11/state_tells_man_he_may_be_jailed_for_releasing_data/ |title=State tells man he may be jailed for releasing data - The Boston Globe |first=Noah |last=Bierman |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=11 November 2010 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[Boston, MA|Boston]] |issn=0743-1791 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.telegram.com/article/20101113/NEWS/11130325/1020 |title=SNAP shot |author=no author listed |work=[[Telegram & Gazette]] |date=13 November 2010 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref> The state later said that it would not jail MuckRock staff.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/11/12/state_cools_threat_to_blogger_over_food_stamp_post/ |title=State cools threat to blogger over food stamp post |first=Jonathan |last=Saltzman |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=12 November 2010 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[Boston, MA|Boston]] |issn=0743-1791 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref>
The [[Boston Police Department]] suspended an [[automatic number plate recognition]] program because of privacy concerns raised after a MuckRock request.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/2013/12/14/boston-police-suspend-use-high-tech-licence-plate-readers-amid-privacy-concerns/FUrus0ktxAt51sAdmLKpPM/story.html?rss_id=Top+Stories |title=Boston Police suspend use of high-tech licence plate readers amid privacy concerns - News Local Massachusetts |first=Shawn |last=Musgrave |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=13 December 2013 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[Boston, MA|Boston]] |issn=0743-1791 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/12/boston-police-indefinitely-suspends-license-plate-reader-program/ |title=Boston Police indefinitely suspends license plate reader program | Ars Technica |first=Cyrus |last=Farvivar |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref>
MuckRock made numerous requests to various United States state and federal agencies regarding their work with [[Booz Allen Hamilton]].<ref name="Masnick">{{cite web |url= http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20130930/16534724704/fbi-wants-more-than-270000-to-respond-to-foia-request-about-booz-allen.shtml |title=FBI Wants More Than $270,000 To Respond To FOIA Request About Booz Allen |first=Mike |last=Masnick |work=[[Techdirt]] |date=1 October 2013 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref> The response from the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] was a bill for USD $270,000 to fulfill the request.<ref name="Masnick"/>
MuckRock's request to the [[New York City Police Department]] for their guidebook on responding to FOIA requests was denied due to it being a confidential document.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://boingboing.net/2014/03/16/nypd-claims-its-freedom-of-inf.html#more-292385 |title=NYPD claims its Freedom of Information Act policy is a secret 'attorney-client communications'|first=Cory |last=Doctorow |work=boingboing.net |date=16 March 2014 |accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref>
==Lawsuit== In June 2014 MuckRock sued the CIA under the Freedom of Information Act for "consistently ignoring deadlines, refusing to work with requesters, and capriciously rejecting even routine requests for what should be clearly public information".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://boingboing.net/2014/06/11/transparency-journalism-site-m.html |title=Transparency journalism site MuckRock sues CIA |first=Xeni |last=Jardin |authorlink=Xeni Jardin |work=boingboing.net |date=11 June 2014 |accessdate=12 June 2014}}</ref>
==Partners== The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] has made public records requests with MuckRock.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2012/10/eff-and-muckrock-have-filed-over-200-public-records-requests-surveillance-drones |title=EFF and MuckRock Have Filed Over 200 Records Requests On Drones And The Results Are Pouring In |first=Trevor |last=Timm |work=eff.org |date=22 October 2012 |accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.muckrock.com}}

'''Mzi Godfrey Khumalo''' (born 1955) is a [[South Africa]]n businessman and [[mining]] entrepreneur.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.financialafrik.com/2017/12/25/les-100-qui-transforment-lafrique-3/|title=Les 100 qui transforment l’Afrique|date=2017-12-25|work=Financial Afrik|access-date=2018-03-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
After serving 12 years<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.africanewsagency.fr/2018/01/27/mzi-khumalo-le-monsieur-mine-du-zimbabwe/|title=Mzi Khumalo : le «Monsieur mine» du Zimbabwe {{!}} ANA - Africa News Agency|website=www.africanewsagency.fr|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref> on [[Robben Island]] alongside figures such as [[Nelson Mandela]] for his anti-apartheid activities,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/markets/article-2897710/Zimbabwe-miner-float-London-2015.html|title=Zimbabwe miner to float in London in 2015|work=This is Money|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref> Mzi has built a corporate empire which encompasses mining, financial services and infrastructure industries and has served on a number of company boards. Mzi was the 27th prisoner of the year 1979 on Robben Island, prison number 2779 and was 24 when he was sentenced to 26 years behind bars for treason, by SA’s apartheid government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.africanewshub.com/search?keywords=decoding+lessons|title=Search :: decoding lessons|last=Hub|first=Africa News|website=www.africanewshub.com|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/opinion/2018-04-27-mzi-khumalo-decoding-lessons-from-robben-island-and-tips-for-africas-emerging-leaders/|title=MZI KHUMALO: Decoding lessons from Robben Island and tips for Africa’s emerging leaders|access-date=2018-04-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
He has held the position of Chairman at various companies including JCI Limited,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/business/companies/sa-seeks-black-champion-to-fill-mining-void-1986315|title=SA seeks ‘black champion’ to fill mining void {{!}} IOL Business Report|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en}}</ref> Capital Alliance Holdings Limited<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/1996-11-29-jci-price-is-inflated|title=JCI price is `inflated'|last=Reporter|first=Staff|work=The M&G Online|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en}}</ref> and Point Waterfront Corporation.
He is also former Non-Executive Director of Mintek, Telkom SA, McCarthy Retail Limited, Ridge Mining and Anglo American Corporation and is a Trustee of the World Wildlife Fund.
Mzi holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree from the [[University of South Africa]].
He is currently Non-Executive Chairman<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20171103-people-profit-gold-prices-mining-industry-petrochina-stock-market-collapse-tamagotchi|title=All that glitters: Gold prices decline over economic optimism - France 24|date=2017-11-02|work=France 24|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en-US}}</ref> of [[Metallon Corporation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://metcorp.co.uk/about-us/board-of-directors.aspx|title=Board of Directors|website=metcorp.co.uk|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref> Additionally, he has interests in the telecommunications industry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bulawayo24.com/index-id-business-sc-companies-byo-61321.html|title=Telecel executive expected in Zimbabwe this week|last=eDuzeNet|work=Bulawayo24 News|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en-GB}}</ref>
He has held the following positions :
* [[Metallon Corporation]], Chairman<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.africa.com/press-statement/|title=Press Statement - Africa.com|website=www.africa.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref> (2001 – Present) * [[Mintek]], Chairman (2004 - 2009) * Ridge Mining, Non-Executive Director (2002 - 2004) * Capital Alliance Holdings, Chairman (1995 - 1998) * JCI Ltd, Chairman (1996 - 1998)
He is the founder of the Mzi & Khosi Khumalo foundation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kearsney.com/foundation/?p=12617|title=Mzi & Khosi Khumalo Family Foundation {{!}} Kearsney College Foundation|website=www.kearsney.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref>

The '''National Information Governance Board for Health and Social Care''' (NIGB) was established in the [[United Kingdom]] under section 157[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2008/14/section/157 Section 157 of the Health and Social Care Act 2008] of the Health and Social Care Act 2008, with effect from October 2008, with a range of advisory functions relating to [[information governance]]. From January 2009, the NIGB also gained functions under section 251[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2006/41/section/251 Section 251 of the NHS Act 2006] of the NHS Act 2006 which had previously been held by the [[Patient Information Advisory Group]] (PIAG) until its abolition. These functions were to advise the [[Secretary of State for Health]] on the use of powers to set aside the common law duty of confidentiality in [[England]] where identifiable patient information is needed and where consent is not practicable. From 1 April 2013, the NIGB's functions for monitoring and improving information governance practice have transferred to the [[Care Quality Commission]], which established a National Information Governance Committee to oversee this work. Functions relating to section 251 of the [[National Health Service Act 2006|NHS Act 2006]] (access to people’s personal and confidential information for research purposes) were transferred to the [[Health Research Authority]]'s Confidentiality Advisory Group.[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130513181011/http://www.nigb.nhs.uk/ Webarchive page of the National Information Governance Board for Health and Social Care] ==Terms of reference== The key functions of the NIGB (excerpted from the legislation) were:
  1. to monitor the practice followed by relevant bodies in relation to the processing of relevant information;
  2. to keep the [[Secretary of State for Health]], and such bodies as the [[Secretary of State for Health]] may designate by direction, informed about the practice being followed by relevant bodies in relation to the processing of relevant information;
  3. to publish guidance on the practice to be followed in relation to the processing of relevant information;
  4. to advise the [[Secretary of State for Health]] on particular matters relating to the processing of relevant information by any person; and
  5. to advise persons who process relevant information on such matters relating to the processing of relevant information by them as the [[Secretary of State for Health]] may from time to time designate by direction.
The definition of “relevant information” in the legislation covers patient information, any other information obtained or generated in the course of the provision of the health service, and any information obtained or generated in the course of the exercise by a local social services authority in [[England]] of its adult social services functions. ==Ethics and Confidentiality Committee== Some areas of NIGB functions (d) and (e) above had been delegated to the NIGB’s Ethics and Confidentiality Committee (ECC). These functions primarily related to applications to use identifiable patient information without consent, in specific circumstances within the bounds of section 251 of the NHS Act 2006. These applications, which had been considered by PIAG before the NIGB, passed on to the [[Health Research Authority]]'s Confidentiality Advisory Group (CAG) on 1 April 2013. ==Care Record Development Board== The NIGB had also replaced the Care Record Development Board (CRDB),[http://www.connectingforhealth.nhs.uk/crdb Care Record Development Board archive page hosted by NHS Connecting for Health] which had closed in September 2007. The NIGB had subsequently maintained the NHS Care Record Guarantee which was originally developed by the CRDB and developed a companion Social Care Record Guarantee. ==Members== The NIGB had consisted of a Chair, a number of Public Members appointed by the NHS Appointments Commission, and a number of Representative Members appointed by the [[Secretary of State for Health]] from a range of stakeholder organisations. Representatives of several other stakeholder organisations had served as Corresponding Advisers to the NIGB but had not typically attended meetings. Regular observers at meetings had included representatives from the [[Information Commissioner's Office]] and the devolved UK administrations. The ECC had consisted of a Chair and a number of Members, all of whom had been appointed by the NIGB with advice from an NHS Appointments Commission approved independent assessor. The ECC Chair and two ECC Members had also been NIGB Members. Between 1 June 2011 and 31 March 2013 Dame [[Fiona Caldicott]][http://www.connectingforhealth.nhs.uk/newsroom/news/nigbchair Appointment of Fiona Caldicott as new NIGB Chair - press release on NHS Connecting for Health website, June 2011] had been Chair of the NIGB, succeeding [[Harry Cayton]] who had chaired the NIGB since its inception. ==Geography== Members of the NIGB and ECC had been widely distributed nationally but had attended meetings at the NIGB office. Since September 2011, this had been based at [[Skipton House]], London SE1. The NIGB’s staff team had been predominantly based at this office. ==Abolition== As a result of the [[Health and Social Care Act 2012]] the NIGB was abolished with effect from 1 April 2013. The functions delegated to the ECC with respect to research transferred to the [[Health Research Authority]].[http://www.hra.nhs.uk/news/2012/12/17/further-update-on-transfer-of-s251-function-from-nigb-to-hra/ Transfer of s251 function from NIGB to HRA] The [[NHS Commissioning Board]] is now responsible for providing advice and guidance to NHS bodies. Other functions were transferred to the National Information Governance Committee hosted by the [[Care Quality Commission]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130513181011/http://www.nigb.nhs.uk/ NIGB website (archived)] *[http://www.hra.nhs.uk/ NHS Health Research Authority] *[http://www.cqc.org.uk/ Care Quality Commission] *[http://www.nres.nhs.uk National Research Ethics Service] *[http://www.commissioningboard.nhs.uk/ NHS Commissioning Board] [[Category:Databases in the United Kingdom‎]] [[Category:Medical privacy]] [[Category:2008 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2008]] [[Category:Governance in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Social care in the United Kingdom]]

{{Multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=February 2011}} {{expert needed|Economics|date=January 2015}} }}
{{Infobox person | name = Nikolai F. Danielson | image = Nikolai Danielson.jpg | alt = | caption = N.F. Danielson | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1844|2|7}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|1918|7|13|1844|2|7}} | death_place = [[Petrograd]] | nationality = Russian | other_names = N-on, Nik-on, Nikolai-on | occupation = Economist and [[sociology|sociologist]] | known_for = }} '''Nikolai Frantsevich Danielson''' ({{lang-ru|Никола́й Фра́нцевич Дание́льсон}}; also known as N-on, Nik-on, Nikolai-on; 7 February 1844, [[Moscow]]{{spaced ndash}}13 July 1918, [[Petrograd]]) was a Russian socio-political figure, economist, publicist, one of the theoreticians of [[liberal populism]].<ref>http://hrono.ru/biograf/bio_d/danielson.php</ref> He is also famous for translation of [[Das Kapital]] by Marx, and being a writer on Russian economic development.<ref>https://books.google.com.ua/books?id=7NgcBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227&dq=Nikolai+Frantsevich+Danielson&source=bl&ots=a0ZQ1C-doM&sig=_Yx7MTHnNfoKSi7apQkh3ZxHUdA&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjLlunq9YLZAhWGCSwKHcsYAsEQ6AEIZjAJ#v=onepage&q=Nikolai%20Frantsevich%20Danielson&f=false</ref>
==Early life== He graduated from [[Commercial School]] in [[St. Petersburg]], and later attended lectures in St. Petersburg's university.<ref>http://hrono.ru/biograf/bio_d/danielson.php</ref>
In the 1860s Danielson worked at the St Petersburg Mutual Credit Association. Mutual credit associations were then often associated with utopian and social reform politics, and during that period, he became involved in radical political circles and took interest in one of the populist ''[[narodnik]]'' movement.
==Economic Writings and Translation of ''Das Kapital''==
In 1872, Danielson published the first Russian translation of volume 1 of ''[[Das Kapital]]'' by [[Karl Marx]]. The translation had been initiated by [[Mikhail Bakunin]] before Bakunin's break with Marx and had been continued by [[German Lopatin]]. While completing the translation, Danielson initiated a correspondence with Karl Marx and Friedrich [[Friedrich Engels|Engels]], which continued for the rest of their lives. Danielson also translated volumes 2 and 3 of ''Das Kapital'', which were published in 1885 and 1896. In 1880 Danielson published the article "Studies of Our Post-Reform Economy" in issue 10 of the journal ''Slovo''. Marx, who had taught himself Russian, commended it and encouraged Danielson to expand it into a book, which Danielson subsequently did. That book, bearing the same title, appeared in 1893. The book and the article on which it was based contained extensive statistical material on Russia's economic development.<ref>https://books.google.com.ua/books?id=SXm9BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA7&lpg=PA7&dq=Nikolai+Frantsevich+Danielson&source=bl&ots=oeEJA0IK-L&sig=G4yU7O8tVPdmT7CuobqFQwk8DV0&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjLlunq9YLZAhWGCSwKHcsYAsEQ6AEIYTAI#v=onepage&q=Nikolai%20Frantsevich%20Danielson&f=false</ref>
==Views on Marxism==
Danielson regarded himself as a [[Marxist]], but was criticized by the self-proclaimed "orthodox" Marxists [[Georgi Plekhanov]], [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Peter Struve]], among others. Danielson's critics grouped him with populist writers like [[Vasily Vorontsov]] and [[Nikolay Mikhaylovsky]]. But whereas Vorontsov claimed that the development of industrial capitalism in Russia was impossible for lack of markets and Mikhailovsky thought that it was possible but undesirable and preventable, Danielson argued that capitalist industrialisation was already well under way in Russia by the 1890s. The "orthodox" Marxists agreed with him in this. However, in the 1890s, Plekhanov, Lenin and their associates argued that capitalism in Russia must follow essentially the same course as capitalist development in Western Europe. Danielson believed that the "capitalist stage" of development could be foreshortened in Russia, since Russia's late development would allow it to adopt the latest western industrial technology without having to undergo the social evolution that had first produced it in the West. This theory went back to A.I. Herzen and N.G. Chernyshevsky and strongly influenced the theoreticians of the [[Socialist-Revolutionary Party]] (PSR), such as [[Victor Chernov]]. It also anticipated [[Leon Trotsky]]'s theory of "uneven and combined development". Danielson argued that capitalism was essentially dispensable for further economic development, and that industrialisation could continue on the basis of a socialist economy. Like the ''narodniks'', he saw the surviving peasant village communes as potential nuclei for a socialist organisation of the Russian economy. Plekhanov and Lenin denounced this as dangerous utopianism.
==Political Involvement==
In the early 1900s, Danielson was briefly involved with the Russian Socialist-Revolutionary Party, but he did not play a very active role in it, and he withdrew after the ''"Azef affair"'' of 1908. ([[Yevno Azef]] was a prominent leader of the PSR and the chief of its terrorist organisation; in 1908 he was unmasked as a double agent for the Okhrana, the secret police.) Danielson seemed to have played no role in the [[Russian Revolution (1917)|Russian Revolution of 1917]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Use British English|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox publisher | image = [[File:Octagon Press Logo.jpg|70px|Official logo]] | founded = 1960 | founder = [[Idries Shah]] | status = Defunct (2014) | distribution = Worldwide | topics = humanities, cultural geography, literature, poetry, folklore, psychology, travel and philosophy | country = {{flagcountry|United Kingdom}} | headquarters = London | url = [http://www.octagonpress.com/ octagonpress.com] }} '''Octagon Press''' was a cross-cultural publishing house based in [[London]], UK. It was founded in 1960 by [[Sufism|Sufi]] teacher, [[Idries Shah]] to establish the historical and cultural context for his ideas.<ref name="DTOB">{{cite web |last = Staff |title = Idries Shah – Grand Sheikh of the Sufis whose inspirational books enlightened the West about the moderate face of Islam (obituary) |work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] |url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/et?ac=001301712421770&rtmo=qMuJX999&atmo=99999999&pg=/et/96/12/7/ebshah07.html |accessdate = 2008-10-16 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20000525070609/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/et?ac=001301712421770&rtmo=qMuJX999&atmo=99999999&pg=%2Fet%2F96%2F12%2F7%2Febshah07.html |archivedate = 25 May 2000 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The company ceased trading in 2014.<ref name="Octagon-Ceased-2014">{{cite web | author = Staff | first = | title = Octagon Press | publisher = Octagon Press | date = 2014 | url = http://www.idriesshahfoundation.org/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141028015956/http://www.octagonpress.com/| archivedate=28 October 2014| accessdate = 2014-10-10}}</ref>
==Description==
Octagon Press published many of Shah's later works.<ref name="OISTI">{{cite news | last = Cecil | first = Robert | title = Obituary: Idries Shah | work = [[The Independent]] | publisher = | date = 1996-11-26 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-idries-shah-1354309.html | accessdate = 2008-11-05}}</ref> In addition, the publishing house has produced translations of Sufi classics<ref name="SW32">{{cite book | last1 = Malik | first1 = Jamal | last2 = Hinnells | first2 = John R. (eds.) | authorlink = | title = Sufism in the West | publisher = Routledge Taylor & Francis Group | year = 2006 | location = London, UK/New York, NY | page = 32 | isbn = 0-415-27407-9}}</ref> and titles by other notable authors, focusing on the fields of the [[humanities]], cultural geography, [[literature]], poetry, [[folklore]], [[psychology]], travel and [[philosophy]].<ref name="OctagonAbout">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = About the Octagon Press | publisher = ''Octagon Press'' | url = http://www.clearlight.com/octagon/about.htm | accessdate = 2008-10-16}}</ref>
Shah used Octagon Press to increase the availability of information on [[Afghanistan]], aware that there would be a need for such information after the country's recent history.<ref name="DTOB" /> Two of his books, ''Darkest England'' (1987) and ''The Natives are Restless'' (1988), "traced affinities between the English and Afghan peoples".<ref name="OISTI" />
For many years Octagon Press sold the academic monographs published by the London [[Institute for Cultural Research]], now sold directly by the ICR. A number of the classical works have been published with the aid of the Sufi Trust.
The Octagon Press Limited was registered in the United Kingdom as a limited liability company at Companies House on 10 January 1972.<ref name="ukdata">[https://www.ukdata.com/company-credit-reports/OCTAGON-PRESS-LIMITED-(THE).html Company details of Octagon Press Limited (The) at ukdata.com]</ref>
In 2014, it was stated on the official web site that "The Octagon Press announces that it is to cease from trading in its current form. The works of Idries Shah will henceforth be represented by ISF Publishing, a part of [[The Idries Shah Foundation]]. Existing editions of Octagon Press titles will no longer be available. Idries Shah's corpus of work will be relaunched in entirety in new printed and eBook editions."<ref name="Octagon-Ceased-2014" />
==Authors== *[[Saira Elizabeth Luiza Shah|Morag Murray Abdullah]], a Scottish travel writer who journeyed through Central Asia. *Jack L. Bracelin, a biographer. One of the first Octagon titles was the biographical work, ''Gerald Gardner: Witch''. Attributed to Jack L. Bracelin, it was in fact ghost-written by Shah, who was [[Gerald Gardner (Wiccan)|Gardner's]] secretary at the time of writing.<ref name="Lamond">{{cite book | last = Lamond | first = Frederic | authorlink = | title = Fifty Years of Wicca | publisher = Green Magic | year = 2004 | location = | page = 9 | isbn = 0-9547230-1-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Pearson | first = Joanne | authorlink = | title = A Popular Dictionary of Paganism | publisher = Routledge Taylor & Francis Group | year = 2002 | location = London, UK/New York, NY | page = 28 | isbn = 0-7007-1591-6}} </ref>
*[[Richard Francis Burton|Sir Richard Burton]], an English [[explorer]], [[translator]], writer, [[soldier]], [[oriental studies|orientalist]], [[ethnologist]], [[linguistics|linguist]], poet, [[hypnotism|hypnotist]], [[fencing|fencer]] and [[diplomat]].<ref name="BurtonBBC">{{cite web|last=Staff |title=Historical figures: Sir Richard Francis Burton (1821 - 1890) |publisher=''[[BBC]] History'' |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/burton_sir_richard_francis.shtml |accessdate=2009-05-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090223170319/http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/burton_sir_richard_francis.shtml |archivedate=23 February 2009 }}</ref> *[[Edward Campbell (journalist)|Edward Campbell]], a [[Fleet Street]] journalist and an acknowledged authority on [[circus]]es and the training of wild animals, who had a book ''The People of the Secret'' published for a time by Octagon, written under the [[pseudonym]] "Ernest Scott".<ref name="Campbell">{{cite web |last = Stacey |first = Don |authorlink = |title = Obituaries: Edward Campbell |work = [[The Stage]] |publisher = |date = 2006-05-18 |url = http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/obituaries/feature.php/12653/edward-campbell |format = |doi = |accessdate = 2008-10-04 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060920063725/http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/obituaries/feature.php/12653/edward-campbell |archivedate = 20 September 2006 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The book featured an introduction by the philosopher and prolific novelist [[Colin Wilson]].

Ornstein|Robert Ornstein]], a psychologist, writer, professor at [[Stanford University]], and chairman of the [[Institute for the Study of Human Knowledge]] (ISHK). *[[Amina Shah]], a prominent anthologiser of Sufi stories and [[Folklore|folk tale]]s,<ref name=Smoley>{{cite book | last = Smoley | first = Richard |author2=Kinney, Jay | authorlink = | title = Hidden Wisdom | publisher = Quest Books | year = 2004 | location = Wheaton, IL/Chennai, India | page = 244 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8356-0844-1}}</ref> who was for many years the Chairperson of the London-based [[College of Storytellers]]. *[[Khalilullah Khalili]], Afghanistan's foremost 20th-century poet.<ref name="Khalili">{{cite web | last = Staff | first = | authorlink = | title = Khalilullah Khalili Dies at 79; Afghan Poet and Ex-Official | work = [[New York Times]] | publisher = | date = 1987-05-14 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/obituaries/khalilullah-khalili-dies-at-79-afghan-poet-and-ex-official.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-05-26}}</ref> The ''Quatrains of Khalilullah Khalili'' is published with both [[Dari (Eastern Persian)|Dari]] and English versions of the text.
*[[Sirdar Ikbal Ali Shah]], an Afghan author, poet, diplomat, scholar, and savant. *[[Idries Shah]], author of over forty books. His most seminal work was ''[[The Sufis]]'', which appeared in 1964 and was well received internationally.<ref name="NYT">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Idries Shah, 72, Indian-Born Writer Of Books on Sufism (obituary) | work = [[New York Times]] | date = 1996-12-02 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/02/us/idries-shah-72-indian-born-writer-of-books-on-sufism.html | accessdate = 2009-05-25}}</ref>
*[[Tahir Shah]], a writer, reviewer, filmmaker and "intrepid traveller".<ref>{{cite web | last = Shah | first = Tahir | authorlink = | title = Expert's Picks: Travel & Adventure | work = [[Washington Post]] | publisher = | date = 2006-07-09 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/06/AR2006070601092.html | doi = | accessdate = 2009-05-26}}</ref> Four of his earlier works, ''[[Beyond the Devil's Teeth]]'', ''[[In Search of King Solomon's Mines]]'', ''[[Sorcerer's Apprentice (book)|Sorcerer's Apprentice]]'' and ''[[The Middle East Bedside Book]]'' are published or distributed by Octagon.
*Denise Winn, a British journalist specializing in psychology and medicine, is a former editor of the UK edition of ''[[Psychology Today]]'', has written for national newspapers and magazines in Britain for over 20 years, and is author of a dozen books on psychological and medical topics. ''The Manipulated Mind : Brainwashing, Conditioning and Indoctrination'' was published by Octagon.<ref name="AmazonWinn">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = The Manipulated Mind : Brainwashing, Conditioning and Indoctrination | publisher = ''Amazon.com'' | url = https://www.amazon.com/Manipulated-Mind-Brainwashing-Conditioning-Indoctrination/dp/1883536227 | accessdate = 2009-05-26}}</ref>
==Classical translations== Notable classical Sufi authors in translation include: *[[Al-Ghazali]]: ''The Alchemy of Happiness'' *Nuruddin [[Jami]]: ''[[Yusuf and Zulaikha]]'' *Jalal ad-Din [[Rumi]]: ''The Teachings of Rumi'' from ''The [[Masnavi]]''. Rumi was a 13th-century [[Persian people|Persian]] [[poet]], Islamic [[jurist]], [[theologian]], and [[Mysticism|mystic]]. He "is one of the most widely read poets in the United States".<ref>{{cite web | last = Staff | first = | authorlink = | title = Poetry of Rumi a Unifying Force of Civilizations | work = | publisher = ''America.gov'' | date = 2008-04-24 | url = http://www.america.gov/st/peopleplace-english/2008/April/20080421141644zjsredna0.6308405.html?CP.rss=true | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-05-26}}</ref> *[[Saadi (poet)|Saadi]] of Shiraz: ''[[Bostan (book)|The Bostan]]'' and ''[[Gulistan of Sa'di|The Gulistan]]'' *Hakim [[Sanai]]: ''The Walled Garden of Truth'' *[[Mahmud Shabistari]]: ''The Secret Garden'' *Shah Waliullah of Delhi: ''The Sacred Knowledge'' *''The Religion of the Sufis'' translated from ''The Dabistan''
The compilation ''Four Sufi Classics'' contains: *Al-Ghazali: ''The Niche for Lights'' *Jami: ''The Abode of Spring'' *Jami: ''Salaman and Absal'' *Sanai: ''The Way of the Seeker''
==Reception== Idries Shah's books on Sufism have achieved wide critical acclaim. He was the subject of a [[BBC]] documentary ("One Pair of Eyes: Dreamwalkers") in 1970,<ref name=MENA /> and two of his works (''[[The Way of the Sufi]]'' and ''Reflections'') were chosen as "Outstanding Book of the Year" by the BBC's "The Critics" programme.<ref name="DLES">{{cite news | last = Lessing | first = Doris |author2=Elwell-Sutton, L. P. | title = Letter to the Editors by Doris Lessing, with a reply by L. P. Elwell-Sutton | work = [[The New York Review of Books]] | publisher = | date = 1970-10-22 | url = http://www.nybooks.com/articles/10797 | accessdate = 2008-11-05}}</ref> Among other honours, Shah won six first prizes at the [[UNESCO]] World Book Year in 1973,<ref name=MENA>{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = The Middle East and North Africa | publisher = Europa Publications Limited, Taylor & Francis Group, International Publications Service | year = 1988 | location = | page = 952 | isbn = 978-0-905118-50-5}}</ref> and the [[Islamic scholar]] [[James Kritzeck]], commenting on Shah's ''[[Tales of the Dervishes]]'', said that it was "beautifully translated".<ref name="DLES" /> At the time of his death, Shah's books had sold over 15 million copies in a dozen languages worldwide.<ref name="Westerlund">{{cite book | last = Westerlund | first = David (ed.) | authorlink = | title = Sufism in Europe and North America | publisher = RoutledgeCurzon | year = 2004 | location = New York, NY | pages = 136–138 | isbn = 0-415-32591-9}}</ref>
Nobel Prize–winning author Doris Lessing, who has also had work published by Octagon Press, praised Shah's many books and saw him as a "good friend and teacher".<ref name="Lessingon" <ref name="Lessingon">{{cite web | last = Lessing | first = Doris | authorlink = <!--Doris Lessing--> | title = On the Death of Idries Shah (excerpt from Shah's obituary in the London ''The Daily Telegraph'') | publisher = dorislessing.org | url = http://www.dorislessing.org/on.html | accessdate = 2008-10-03}}</ref>
==Relief efforts== Idries Shah set up a charitable agency, Afghan Relief<ref name="AR">Afghan Relief was registered with the UK Charity Commission (no. 289910). It was founded 25 July 1984 and ceased to exist and was removed from the registry on 3 October 2002. See [http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/ShowCharity/RegisterOfCharities/RemovedCharityMain.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=289910&SubsidiaryNumber=0 Charity Commission record]. It used the same Post Office box number in London as the Society for Sufi Studies for its [https://www.help.co.uk/charities/78343 address]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> which operated from 1984 to 2002. Its aim was to provide medical, educational and other aid to refugees<ref name="OISTI" /> and Shah wrote books to assist in the operation, some of which are published by Octagon. The relief effort is also now carried out in association with The Institute for the Study Of Human Knowledge (ISHK) and their children's imprint, Hoopoe Books. Hoopoe provides books and complementary teaching materials to schools and children in Afghanistan, with official permission from Afghanistan's Minister of Education in Kabul.<ref name="HoopoeAfghanistan">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Hoopoe Children's Books: Books for Afghanistan | publisher = ''Hoopoe Books'' | url = http://www.hoopoekids.com/afghanistan.htm | accessdate = 2009-05-26}}</ref> Hoopoe also provides relief for Pakistan.
The ''Kite Runner companion curriculum'', published by [[Amnesty International]] USA contains a list of books recommended for further reading by the [[Afghanistan Relief Organization]] (ARO, founded in 1998 and not to be confused with Shah's original Afghan Relief).<ref name="ARO">Afghanistan Relief Organization (ARO) is a non-political, non-religious, nonprofit 501(c)(3) humanitarian organization, registered in the United States and in Afghanistan, founded in the United States in 1998.</ref> These recommended books include several works for children by Idries Shah published by Hoopoe, and [[Ikbal Ali Shah]]'s ''Afghanistan of the Afghans'' and works by [[Saira Shah|Saira]] and [[Safia Shah]] published by Octagon.<ref name="AmnestyUSA">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = The Kite Runner companion curriculum (pdf) | publisher = ''[[Amnesty International]] USA'' | url = http://www.amnestyusa.org/education/pdf/kiterunnerhigh.pdf | accessdate = 2009-05-26}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} '''Paris Economy Pact''' was an international economic agreement reached at the '''Paris Economic Conference''' held from 14 June 1916 in [[Paris, France]]. The meeting, held at the height of [[World War I]], included representatives of the [[Allies of World War I|Allied Powers]]: [[United Kingdom]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], and [[Russia]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=RXgAAAAAYAAJ William S. Culbertson, ''Commercial Policy and the War'', The Century Illustrated Monthly Magazine, 1919, pp. 137-38.]</ref>
The pact was intended to isolate the [[Central Powers]], the [[German Empire]], the [[Austrian-Hungarian Empire]], the [[Ottoman Empire]] and the [[Kingdom of Bulgaria]]. The Allied Powers envisioned isolating the [[Central Powers]] through trade sanctions after the war. A standing body, the ''Comité Permanent International d'Action Économique'', based in Paris, was established to monitor the implementation of the pact.
This pact was of great concern to the United States government, led by the [[Presidency of Woodrow Wilson|Wilson Administration]], which saw the continued fragmentation of Europe to be a risk for continued conflict.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=s6dSIuBcx1IC David M. Kennedy, ''Over Here: The First World War and American Society'', 2004, p. 308.]</ref> U.S. Secretary of State [[Robert Lansing]] asked the staff of the U.S. Embassy in Paris to monitor the proceedings (the United States, having not yet entered the war, was not part of the [[Allies of World War I|Allied Powers]]). The issue of central concern to the United States was that this pact included schemes for subsidization and government ownership of manufacturing enterprises and the division of European markets for the pact participants.
The outcome of the 1916 Paris Economic Conference foreshadowed the conflict between the United States and the [[Allies of World War I|Allied Powers]] during the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=zqj-oHp4KsgC Elizabeth Glaser, ''The Making of the Economic Peace'' in The Treaty of Versailles: A Reassessment after 75 Years, 1998, p. 374.]</ref>
The past concern of the U.S. government with this Pact are fossilized even today in the [[United States Code]], in Title 19, Section 1332(c), which gives the [[U.S. International Trade Commission]] the "power to investigate the Paris Economy Pact and similar organizations and arrangements in Europe."

{{italic title}} {{undue|reason=Not only applied in Austria, but e.g. also in Switzerland|date=October 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2008}} '''''Proporz''''' ({{IPA-de|pʁoˈpɔʁts|lang}}, from ''[[wikt:Proportion#German|Proportionalität]]'') is a long-standing doctrine within the [[Politics of Austria|politics of the second Austrian republic]] that government posts be allocated to parties in proportion to their electoral support. However, recent developments, both internal and external, have arguably weakened the influence of the Proporz system in Austrian politics.
== The underlying principle == Under the Proporz system, the posts of [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]] [[Political minister|Minister]]s are filled by [[political party|party members]] as closely as possible in [[ratio|proportion]] to the [[Voting|vote]]s won by their respective parties in the general elections. Furthermore, the particular portfolios are selected by each party on the basis of its constituency or any perceived ideological [[Mandate (politics)|mandate]] to them.
Thus, for example, the portfolio of Minister for Labour and Social Affairs was nearly always held by a member of the [[Social Democratic Party of Austria]] (SPÖ), while the conservative [[Austrian People's Party]] (ÖVP), with traditionally strong support from [[farmer]]s, took the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, Environment, & Water.
In this basic form, the principle would not be exclusive to Austria, but would be an element of many countries which have [[coalition government]]s.
== Origins == The Proporz system arose out of the need for balanced, [[consensus|consensual governance]] in the early years of Austria's second republic. At the time, the nation was consumed in an effort to rebuild the country after the devastation of [[World War II]]. Moreover, the nation was still haunted by the specter of the ideological factionalism which had characterized [[First Austrian Republic|Austria's first republic]] (cf. the events of the [[Austrian Civil War]]). Thus, the doctrine of Proporz is intimately linked to the idea of the [[grand coalition]], in which the major political parties, in the case of post-war Austria the SPÖ and the ÖVP, share in the government.
The memories of the factionalism that characterised the First Republic were so strong that even after the ÖVP won an absolute majority in the first postwar election, in [[Austrian legislative election, 1945|1945]], it immediately sought a coalition with the SPÖ. Even when one major party governed alone (as the ÖVP did from 1966 to 1970 and the SPÖ did from 1970 to 1983), the other party was never really shut out of decision-making.
== Degeneration and reform == However, the doctrine was later charged with having degenerated into a system of patronage and [[nepotism]] pervading too many aspects of Austrian life. Positions down to minor [[bureaucracy|bureaucratic]] posts were commonly allocated by party membership. The reaches of Proporz went as far as the educational system and even the banking business, in which political parties and municipalities were traditionally tightly involved.
Resentment of the system among large reaches of the population had become widespread by the late 1990s, and it is believed that [[Jörg Haider]]'s criticism of Proporz gained him the support of many centrist voters who were not necessarily supporters of his [[nationalism|nationalist]] and anti-immigration rhetoric.
When his then-party, the [[Freedom Party of Austria]] (FPÖ), joined the government in 2000, many were expecting a discontinuation of the system in all fields except government itself. However, few people today would claim that this has happened. Haider's followers contend that reforms were stymied by the resistance of the FPÖ's coalition partner, the Austrian People's Party (ÖVP). His detractors hold that Haider had never had a true reform in mind, but merely endeavoured to heave members of his own political disposition into positions of power (a practice referred to as ''umfärben'' in German, which roughly translates as 're-coloring').
It is probably fair to say that the major impetus for the rescaling of Austria's system of Proporz was of an external nature. Austria's membership in the [[European Union]] reduced the degree to which government is allowed to interfere in private businesses such as telecommunications and banking, where Proporz had been all-pervading.
A diversified media and the possibilities of modern information technology also hold the government to higher standards of transparency and accountability. Above all, there has been a sea change in the public's attitude to the practice and its willingness to confront it.
In conclusion, it can be argued that while they have not altogether vanished from the politics of Austria, the ideas of Proporz are much less pervasive today than they were only a decade ago.

{{Original research|date=August 2011}} [[File:Czerny-chicos-de-lenin--outlawsdiary02tormuoft.png|thumb|József Cserny with members of the "[[Lenin Boys]]".]] The '''Red Terror''' in Hungary ({{lang-hu|vörösterror}}) was a period of heightened political tension and suppression in 1919 during the four-month period of the [[Hungarian Soviet Republic]], primarily towards [[anti-communists|anti-communist]] forces. The [[communist party]] and [[communist]] policies had considerable popular support among the proletarian masses of large industrial centers - especially in Budapest - where the working class represented a higher ratio of the inhabitants.<ref>{{cite book|author=Robin Okey|title=Eastern Europe 1740-1985: Feudalism to Communism|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=2003|page=162|ISBN=9781134886876|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-8qIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA162&dq=%22bitterly+unpopular+in+the+countryside%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiS9vCVw6DbAhVJaFAKHWbVDXkQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=%22bitterly%20unpopular%20in%20the%20countryside%22&f=false}}</ref> In the Hungarian countryside, the authority of the government was often nonexistent, serving as a launch-point for anti-communist insurgency.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[John Lukacs]]|title=Budapest 1900: A Historical Portrait of a City and Its Culture|publisher=[[Grove Press]]|year=1990|page=2012|ISBN=9780802132505|url=https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=ajeNDt-QsyIC&q=%22over+the+Hungarian+countryside+was+often+nonexistent%22#v=snippet&q=%22over%20the%20Hungarian%20countryside%20was%20often%20nonexistent%22&f=false}}</ref> The new government followed the Soviet solution: the party established its revolutionary terror groups (such as the infamous "[[Lenin Boys]]") to "overcome the obstacles" of the worker's revolution. It received its name in reference to the [[Red Terror]] of [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]]. It was soon followed by the [[White Terror (Hungary)|White Terror]] against communists, industrial workers and Jews.
==History==
In March 1919, the [[Hungarian Communist Party|Party of Communists in Hungary]], in alliance with the [[Social Democratic Party of Hungary]], gained control of the government of Hungary after president [[Mihály Károlyi]] stepped aside. Soon after, a coup by Party of Communists in Hungary, led by [[Béla Kun]], established the [[Hungarian Soviet Republic]].
[[Tibor Szamuely]]<ref>Szamuely Tibor in 20th of April 1919. said on a speech in Győr: "Now the power is in our hands. Who wants the old reign to come back, they should be hanged quickly. The one of this kind must be neck-bitten. The victory of Hungarian proletariat till this time required no serious numbers of victims. But now there is the need of bloodshed. We mustn't be afraid of blood, the blood is like steel: strengthens the hearth and strengthens the proletarian class. Blood will make us gigantean. [...] We will exterminate the whole bourgeoisie, if we have to."{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}}</ref> wrote in the pages of the ''Vörös Újság'' (''Red News''): "Everywhere [[Counter-revolutionary|counter-revolutionaries]] run about and swagger; beat them down! Beat their heads where you find them! If [[Counter-revolutionary|counter-revolutionaries]] were to gain the upper hand for even a single hour, there will be no mercy for any proletarian. Before they stifle the revolution, suffocate them in their own blood!"<ref>''Vörös Újság'', 11 February 1919</ref> With their support, [[József Cserny]] organised a group of some 200 individuals known as "Lenin Boys" (''Lenin-fiúk''), whose intention was to uncover "counter-revolutionary" activities in the Hungarian countryside. Similar groups operated within Budapest.
Two months after gaining power, the government attempted to restore Hungary to its [[Kingdom of Hungary|pre-World War I boundaries]], first by recapturing parts of present-day [[Slovakia]], and then attempting to recapture Transylvania from Romania. These unsuccessful recapture attempts, as well as the inefficacy of the government during the war period, lowered the popular support for the Communist Party, and on June 24 the Social Democratic Party attempted a coup to take control of the government. This attempted coup failed, and in its wake a series of reprisal arrests and lootings occurred in retaliation against the Social Democrats.<ref>[http://www.vjrktf.hu/carus/honisme/ho030400.htm Honismeret] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071102054519/http://www.vjrktf.hu/carus/honisme/ho030400.htm |date=2007-11-02 }} 2003</ref><ref>{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}[http://kalocsa.hit.hu/Lap22222.htm A modernizacia kora] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021133648/http://kalocsa.hit.hu/Lap22222.htm |date=2007-10-21 }} 2003</ref>
The revolutionary tribunals executed between 370 and 587 of those in custody;<ref>Sorensen: "Did Hungary Become Fascist?"; see Leslie Eliason - Lene Bogh Sorensen: ''Fascism, Liberalism, and Social Democracy in Central Europe'': Past and Present, Aarhus Universitetsforlag, 2002, {{ISBN|87-7288-719-2}}</ref> others have placed the number at 590.<ref>Tibor Hajdu. ''The Hungarian Soviet Republic''. Studia Historica. Vol. 131. Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae. Budapest, 1979</ref>
The [[Hungarian Soviet Republic]] ended in the first week of August 1919, when Romanian forces pushed all the way into Budapest. Kun went into exile in Russia; Szamuely fled to Austria but was captured and killed there. József Cserny was arrested and tried in November 1919; the Hungarian Bar Association refused to defend him at trial, so a lawyer was appointed by the court.<ref>"Magyar Reds On Trial," ''New York Times'', November 27, 1919</ref> He was executed in December.
As was common in the political unrest of the 20th century, the Red Terror was answered by a wave of counter-reprisals once the Party of Communists leadership fled. These attacks on leftists, remaining revolutionaries and Jews are known as the "[[White Terror (Hungary)|White Terror]]"<ref>Bodo, Bela, ''Paramilitary Violence in Hungary after the First World War'', East European Quarterly, Vol. 38, 2004</ref> and were far more brutal, extensive and indiscriminate than the Red Terror.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=MMYOx7QnHPwC&pg=PA202&dq=white+terror+hungary+victims&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3numgvavTAhVJJsAKHYuGCxcQ6AEIMDAC#v=onepage&q=white%20terror%20hungary%20victims&f=false|title=The Politics of Backwardness in Hungary, 1825-1945|last=Janos|first=Andrew C.|date=2012-01-20|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=|isbn=1400843022|location=|pages=202|language=en}}</ref><ref>[[White Terror (Hungary)|White Terror]]</ref>
